text: Introduction
label: Title

text: The term ‘modern architecture’ is ambiguous. It can be understood to
label: Paragraph

text: refer to all buildings of the modern period regardless of their ideolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical basis, or it can be understood more specifically as an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: conscious of its own modernity and striving for change. It is in the
label: Paragraph

text: latter sense that it has generally been defined in histories of contem-
label: Paragraph

text: porary architecture, and the present book follows this tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Already in the early nineteenth century, there was wide dissatisfaction
label: Paragraph

text: with eclecticism among architects, historians, and critics. This well-
label: Paragraph

text: documented attitude justifies a history of modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: concerned primarily with reformist, ‘avant-garde’ tendencies, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than one that attempts to deal with the whole of architectural produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion as if it operated within a non-ideological, neutral field.
label: Paragraph

text: It is in the space between the idealist utopias of the historical avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardes and the resistances, complexities, and pluralities of capitalist
label: Title

text: culture that this book seeks to situate itself. Though not attempting to
label: Paragraph

text: be in any way encyclopedic, the narrative follows an overall chronolog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical sequence, and tries to be, perhaps, less certain in its outcome and
label: Paragraph

text: less triumphalist than those of most previous histories of modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: The book consists of a number of essays that can be read either as self-
label: Paragraph

text: contained narratives or as part of a larger whole, each dealing with a
label: Paragraph

text: cluster of related themes reflecting an important moment in the con-
label: Paragraph

text: frontation of architecture with the external conditions of modernity. If
label: Paragraph

text: it is still largely a history of the masters, that is because that was the
label: Paragraph

text: nature of modernism itself, despite its many claims to anonymity.
label: Paragraph

text: A word on terminology: I use—more or less interchangeably—the
label: Paragraph

text: terms ‘modern architecture’, ‘Modernism, ‘the avant-garde’, to mean
label: Paragraph

text: the progressive movements of the 1910s and 19208 as a whole. I also
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally use the term ‘historical avant-garde’, which has the effect
label: Paragraph

text: of historicizing the movement and distinguishing it from contempo-
label: Paragraph

text: rary practice. I do not follow Peter Birger (Theory of the Avant-Garde,
label: Paragraph

text: 1984), who, in the context of Dada photomontage, distinguishes
label: Paragraph

text: between an avant-garde that sought to change the status of art within
label: Paragraph

text: the relations of production and a Modernism that sought only to
label: Paragraph

text: change its forms. That these two polar positions can be applied to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is undeniable. But the line between them is hard to define,
label: Paragraph

text: and even the work of the Left Constructivists and Marxists like Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer does not, in my opinion, escape aestheticism. This is hardly sur-
label: Paragraph

text: prising, since, before it could be separated from the classical-academic
label: Paragraph

text: theory of the arts, aesthetics had first to become an autonomous cate-
label: Paragraph

text: gory. Apart from the general terms mentioned above—which are useful
label: Paragraph

text: precisely because of their semantic vagueness—other terms are used,
label: Paragraph

text: either to define well-attested sub-movements, such as Futurism, Con-
label: Paragraph

text: structivism, De Stijl, LEsprit Nouveau, and the Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Title

text: (New Objectivity), or migratory tendencies within the overall phe-
label: Paragraph

text: nomenon of modernism, such as organicism, neoclassicism,
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism, functionalism, and rationalism. I have tried to explain
label: Paragraph

text: what I mean by these slippery terms in the appropriate chapters.
label: Paragraph

text: From a certain perspective, general terms such as ‘modernism’ can
label: Paragraph

text: also be applied to Art Nouveau—as, indeed, the temporal span of this
label: Paragraph

text: book implies. To try to avoid such ambiguities would be to make
label: Paragraph

text: unsustainable claims for logic. Art Nouveau was both the end and the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of an era, and its achievements as well as its limitations were
label: Paragraph

text: the result of this Janus-like perspective.
label: Paragraph

text: Many aspects of Modernist theory still seem valid today. But much
label: Paragraph

text: in it belongs to the realm of myth, and is impossible to accept at face
label: Paragraph

text: value. The myth itself has now become history, and demands critical
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation. One of the main ideas motivating the protagonists of
label: Paragraph

text: the Modern Movement was the Hegelian notion that the study of
label: Paragraph

text: history made it possible to predict its future course. But it is scarcely
label: Paragraph

text: possible any longer to believe—as the Modernist architects appear to
label: Paragraph

text: have believed—that the architect is a kind of seer, uniquely gifted with
label: Paragraph

text: the power of discerning the spirit of the age and its symbolic forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Such a belief was predicated on the possibility of projecting the condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of the past onto the present. For progressive-minded architects of
label: Paragraph

text: the nineteenth century and their twentieth-century successors, it
label: Paragraph

text: seemed essential to create a unified architectural style that would reflect
label: Paragraph

text: its age, just as previous styles had reflected theirs. This meant the rejec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of an academic tradition that had degenerated into eclecticism,
label: Paragraph

text: imprisoned in a history that had come to an end and whose forms could
label: Paragraph

text: only be endlessly recycled. It did not imply a rejection of tradition as
label: Paragraph

text: such. The architecture of the future would return to the frve tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: in which, it was believed, a harmonious and organic unity had existed
label: Paragraph

text: between all the cultural phenomena of each age. In the great historical
label: Paragraph

text: periods artists had not been free to choose the style in which they
label: Paragraph

text: worked. Their mental and creative horizons had been circumscribed by
label: Paragraph

text: a range of forms that constituted their entire universe. The artist came
label: Paragraph

text: into a world already formed. The study of history seemed to reveal that
label: Paragraph

text: these periods constituted indivisible totalities. On the one hand, there
label: Paragraph

text: were elements unique to each period; on the other, the organic unity
label: Paragraph

text: that bound these elements together was itself a universal. The new age
label: Paragraph

text: must exhibit the cultural totality characteristic of all historical periods.
label: Paragraph

text: The question was never asked how a cultural totality, which by defi-
label: Paragraph

text: nition had depended on an involuntary collective will, could now be
label: Paragraph

text: achieved voluntarily by a number of individuals. Nor did it ever seem to
label: Paragraph

text: have occurred to those who held this view that what separated the past
label: Paragraph

text: from the present might be precisely the absence of this inferred organic
label: Paragraph

text: unity. According to the model of the organic unity of culture, the task of
label: Paragraph

text: the architect was first to uncover and then create the unique forms of
label: Paragraph

text: the age. But the possibility of such an architecture depended on a defin-
label: Paragraph

text: ition of modernity that filtered out the very factors that differentiated it
label: Paragraph

text: most strongly from earlier traditions: capitalism and industrialization.
label: Paragraph

text: William Morris, the founder of the Arts and Crafts movement, had
label: Paragraph

text: rejected both capitalism and machine production, a position that was at
label: Paragraph

text: least consistent. But the theorists of the German Werkbund, while they
label: Paragraph

text: rejected capitalism, wanted to retain industrialization. They con-
label: Paragraph

text: demned what they saw as the materialistic values of both Marxism and
label: Paragraph

text: Western liberal democracy, but sought an alternative that would
label: Paragraph

text: combine the benefits of modern technology with a return to the pre-
label: Paragraph

text: ndustrial community values that capitalism was in the process of
label: Paragraph

text: destroying. The Modern Movement was both an act of resistance to
label: Paragraph

text: social modernity and an enthusiastic acceptance of an open technologi-
label: Paragraph

text: cal future. It longed for a world of territorial and social fixity, while at
label: Paragraph

text: the same time embracing, incompatibly, an economy and technology in
label: Paragraph

text: flux. It shared this belief in a mythical ‘third way’ between capitalism
label: Paragraph

text: and communism with the Fascist movements of the 1930s, and though
label: Paragraph

text: it would be completely wrong to brand it with the crimes of Fascism, it
label: Paragraph

text: is surely no accident that the period of its greatest intensity coincided
label: Paragraph

text: be
label: Title

text: with the anti-democratic, totalitarian political movements that were
label: Paragraph

text: such a dominant feature of the first half of the twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: The conclusion would seem inescapable that the cultural unity and
label: Paragraph

text: shared artistic standards—whether deriving from folk or from aristo-
label: Paragraph

text: cratic traditions—demanded by the modern movement from its
label: Paragraph

text: inception were increasingly out of step with the political and economic
label: Paragraph

text: realities of the twentieth century. Based on an idealist and teleological
label: Paragraph

text: conception of history, modernist theory seems radically to have mis-
label: Paragraph

text: read the very Zeitgeist it had itself invoked, ignoring the complex and
label: Paragraph

text: indeterminate nature of modern capitalism, with its dispersal of power
label: Paragraph

text: and its constant state of movement.
label: Paragraph

text: The revolution of modernism—partly voluntary, partly involun-
label: Paragraph

text: tary—has irrevocably changed the course of architecture. But in the
label: Paragraph

text: process it has itself become transformed. Its totalizing ambitions can
label: Paragraph

text: no longer be sustained. Yet, the adventure of the Modern Movement is
label: Paragraph

text: still capable of acting as an inspiration for a present whose ideals are so
label: Paragraph

text: much less clearly defined. It is the aim of this book to sharpen our
label: Paragraph

text: image of that adventure.

text: Art Nouveau |
label: Title

text: In 1892 the short-lived but vigorous Art Nouveau movement was
label: Paragraph

text: launched in Belgium and quickly spread, first to France and then to the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of Europe. Its inspiration came from the English Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: movement and developments in wrought iron technology, particularly as
label: Paragraph

text: interpreted by the French architect and theorist, Eugéne-Emmanuel Viollet-
label: Paragraph

text: le-Duc (1814-79). The movement was closely associated with the rise ofa
label: Paragraph

text: new industrial bourgeoisie on the one hand and, on the other, with the
label: Paragraph

text: many movements for political independence in fin-de-siécle Europe. It
label: Paragraph

text: spread rapidly by means of journals such as The Studie, which included
label: Paragraph

text: high-quality, mass-produced images, made possible by the new print-
label: Paragraph

text: ing techniques of offset lithography and photolithography which came
label: Paragraph

text: into commercial use in the 1880s and 18gos.
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau was the first systematic attempt to replace the classical
label: Paragraph

text: system of architecture and the decorative arts that had been handed
label: Paragraph

text: down from the seventcenth century and was enshrined in the teaching
label: Paragraph

text: of the Beaux-Arts academies. The new movement abandoned the
label: Paragraph

text: post-Renaissance convention of realism, drawing inspiration from
label: Paragraph

text: styles outside the classical canon—from Japan, from the Middle Ages,
label: Paragraph

text: and even from Rococo. Though it lasted barely 15 years, many of its pre-
label: Paragraph

text: cepts were incorporated into the avant-garde movements that
label: Paragraph

text: followed.
label: Paragraph

text: Like all progressive movements of the late nineteenth and early
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth centuries, Art Nouveau was caught in an inherent
label: Paragraph

text: dilemma—how to preserve the historical values of art under condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions of industrial capitalism. The Industrial Revolution had radically
label: Paragraph

text: altered both the individual and the collective conditions of artistic
label: Paragraph

text: production. In the face of this situation Art Nouveau artists and
label: Paragraph

text: architects reacted in a way that would become typical of later avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardes: they leapt over recent history to a remote and idealized past in
label: Paragraph

text: order to find an art that could be historically justified and yet be
label: Paragraph

text: absolutely new.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Art Nouveau was preceded and profoundly influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by the Arts and Crafts movement, the two continued in parallel, cach
label: Paragraph

text: modifying the other. In Austria, and to some extent in England, there
label: Paragraph

text: was a fusion of the two movements. In Germany the influence of the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts proved the stronger of the two, leading to the
label: Paragraph

text: Deutscher Werkbund and the alliance between industry and the
label: Title

text: decorative arts.
label: Paragraph

text: Antecedents
label: Title

text: The reform of the industrial arts
label: Title

text: Art Nouveau was the outcome of a transformation in the industrial, or
label: Paragraph

text: decorative, arts that had been initiated in England and France earlier
label: Paragraph

text: in the nineteenth century. As early as 1835 a parliamentary commission
label: Paragraph

text: had been set up in England to study the problem of the decline in artis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic quality of machine-made objects and the consequent damage to the
label: Paragraph

text: export market. In 1851 a Great Exhibition of Industry of all Nations
label: Paragraph

text: was organized in London, following a similar but abortive project in
label: Paragraph

text: France. (France had led the way in industrial exhibitions but these had
label: Paragraph

text: been exclusively national.) The Great Exhibition was a huge commer-
label: Paragraph

text: cial and political success, but it confirmed the low quality of decorative
label: Paragraph

text: products not only in England but in all the industrial countries, com-
label: Paragraph

text: pared to those of the East. This realization prompted a succession of
label: Paragraph

text: initiatives both in England and France . In England, the Victoria and
label: Paragraph

text: Albert Museum and the Department of Practical Art were founded in
label: Paragraph

text: 1852, and a spate of books on the decorative arts appeared, including
label: Paragraph

text: the influential Grammar of Ornament (1856) by Owen Jones (1809-74).
label: Paragraph

text: In France, the Comité central des beaux-arts appliqués 4 l'industrie
label: Paragraph

text: was founded (also in 1852), followed by the Union centrale des beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: arts appliqués a I’ndustrie (1864), which later became the Union
label: Paragraph

text: centrale des arts décoratifs.
label: Paragraph

text: Though originating from the same concerns, these institutional
label: Paragraph

text: reforms resulted in a different development in each country. In
label: Paragraph

text: England, after the government initiatives of the 1830s, the reform of
label: Paragraph

text: the arts became a private affair, dominated by a single individual, the
label: Paragraph

text: artist and poet William Morris (1834-96). For Morris, as for the
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher-critic John Ruskin (1819-1900), the reform of the indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial arts was impossible under the present conditions of industrial
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism by which the artist was alienated from the product of his
label: Paragraph

text: labour. In 1861, he set up the firm of Morris, Marshall, and Faulkner to
label: Paragraph

text: create a context for artists to relearn the various crafts under conditions
label: Paragraph

text: as near as possible to those of the medieval guilds. Morris’s initiative
label: Paragraph

text: was followed up by others, creating what was to become known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts movement.
label: Paragraph

text: The situation in France was different. First there was a politically
label: Paragraph

text: influential art establishment, based on the Academy, fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: conservative, but aware of the need for reform and eager to promote it.*
label: Paragraph

text: Secondly, the abolition of the guilds during the French Revolution had
label: Paragraph

text: not destroyed artisanal traditions in France as thoroughly as the
label: Paragraph

text: Industrial Revolution had those of England. When they began experi-
label: Paragraph

text: menting with new techniques and forms in the 1870s, artists and
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen working in the decorative arts such as Eugéne Rousseau
label: Paragraph

text: (1827-91), Felix Bracquemond (1833-1914), and Emile Gallé (1846-1904)
label: Paragraph

text: were able to build upon existing craft traditions. The ultimate model for
label: Paragraph

text: both English and French artists was the medieval guild, but in France
label: Paragraph

text: this model was combined with the more recent domestic tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: Rococo.
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc and structural rationalism
label: Title

text: The Arts and Crafts movement and its off-shoot, the English ‘free-
label: Paragraph

text: style’ house were to have a considerable influence on the development
label: Paragraph

text: of Art Nouveau. But there was another influence at work as well—the
label: Paragraph

text: use of iron as an expressive architectural medium. The role of iron in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture had been central to the debates between traditionalist and
label: Paragraph

text: progressive-positivist architects in France throughout the nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: century. The debate was stimulated by the projects of the Saint-
label: Paragraph

text: Simonian engineers and entrepreneurs who were largely responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for laying down the French technical infrastructure in the 1840s and
label: Paragraph

text: 1850s, and by discussions in the progressive magazine Revue de
label: Paragraph

text: l'Architecture under the editorship of César-Denis Daly (1811-93). But
label: Paragraph

text: it was chiefly through the theories and designs of Viollet-le-Duc that
label: Paragraph

text: iron became associated with the reform of the decorative arts, and that
label: Paragraph

text: an idealist decorative movement became grafted onto the positivist
label: Paragraph

text: structural tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: The career of Viollet-le-Duc had been devoted to the distillation of
label: Paragraph

text: the rational and vitalistic core of Gothic architecture, which he saw as
label: Paragraph

text: the only true basis for a modern architecture. The main precepts
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet bequeathed to the Art Nouveau movement were: the exposure
label: Paragraph

text: of the armature of a building as a visually logical system; the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: organization of its parts according to function rather than to rules of
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry and proportion; the importance of materials and their
label: Title

text: properties as generators of form; the concept of organic form, deriving
label: Paragraph

text: from the Romantic movement; and the study of vernacular domestic
label: Title

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Through two of his many books, Entretiens sur [’Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (Lectures on Architecture) and the Dictionnaire Raisonné de l’Architecture
label: Title

text: Francaise (Dictionary of French Architecture), Viollet-le-Duc became
label: Paragraph

text: the rallying point for all those opposed to the Beaux-Arts. This was
label: Paragraph

text: true not only in France, where ‘alternative ateliers’ were set up (though
label: Paragraph

text: these were soon reabsorbed into the Beaux-Arts system),’ but also
label: Paragraph

text: elsewhere in Europe and in North America. His influence on the Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau movement came from both his theory and his designs.
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolism
label: Title

text: Most historians* agree that important changes took place in the intel-
label: Paragraph

text: lectual climate of Western Europe in the last two decades of the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century. The century had been dominated by a belief in
label: Paragraph

text: progress made possible by science and technology, a belief that found
label: Paragraph

text: its philosophical formulation in the movement known as Positivism
label: Paragraph

text: founded by Auguste Comte (1798-1857). In literature and art it was
label: Paragraph

text: Naturalism that corresponded most closely to the prevailing Positivist
label: Paragraph

text: frame of mind. But by the 1880s belief in Positivism had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: erode, together with the faith in liberal politics that had supported
label: Paragraph

text: it. Several political events no doubt contributed to this phenomenon,
label: Paragraph

text: including the terrible European economic depression that began
label: Paragraph

text: In France, the home of Positivism, the change of intellectual
label: Paragraph

text: climate was especially noticeable, and it was accompanied by a signifi-
label: Paragraph

text: cant increase in the influence of German philosophy. In literature, the
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolist movement led the attack. The Symbolists held that art
label: Paragraph

text: should not imitate appearances but should reveal an essential underly-
label: Paragraph

text: ing reality. This idea had been anticipated by Baudelaire, whose poem
label: Paragraph

text: Correspondences (which incorporated Emanuel Swedenborg’s theory of
label: Paragraph

text: synaesthesia, though probably unknowingly), gives voice to the idea
label: Paragraph

text: that the arts are intimately related to each other at a profound level:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘like long echoes which from afar become confused . . . Perfumes,
label: Paragraph

text: colours, and sounds respond to each other.’ In describing the move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, the Belgian Symbolist poet Emile Verhaeren compared German
label: Paragraph

text: to French thought, to the detriment of the latter: ‘In Naturalism [is
label: Paragraph

text: found] the French philosophy of the Comtes and the Littrés; in
label: Paragraph

text: [Symbolism] the German philosophy of Kant and Fichte . . . In the
label: Paragraph

text: latter, the fact and the world become a mere pretext for the idea; they
label: Paragraph

text: are treated as appearance, condemned to incessant variability, appear-
label: Paragraph

text: ing ultimately as dreams in our mind.”* The Symbolists did not reject
label: Paragraph

text: the natural sciences, but looked on science as the verification of subjec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive states of mind. As one contributor (probably Verhaeren) to the
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolist journal L’Art Moderne said: ‘Since the methods that were
label: Paragraph

text: formerly instinctive have become scientific .. . a change has been pro-
label: Paragraph

text: duced in the personality of artists.”
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In his book Du dessin et de la couleur (Drawing and Colour), published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1885, the ceramicist Felix Bracquemond defined the new concept in the
label: Paragraph

text: following terms: ‘Ornament does not necessarily copy nature even
label: Paragraph

text: when it borrows from her . . . Its infidelity to her . . . [is] due to the fact
label: Paragraph

text: that it is solely concerned with embellishing surfaces, that it depends
label: Paragraph

text: on the materials it has to adorn, on the forms it has to follow without
label: Paragraph

text: altering them.”
label: Paragraph

text: In Art Nouveau, this ‘functional’ dependency of ornament led to a
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxical reversal. Instead of merely obeying the form of the object,
label: Paragraph

text: ornament began to merge with the object, animating it with new life.
label: Paragraph

text: This had two effects: first, the object became thought of as a single
label: Paragraph

text: organic entity rather than as an aggregation of separate parts, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: classical tradition; second, ornament was no longer thought of as ‘space
label: Paragraph

text: filling’, and a dialogue was set up between two positive values—orna-
label: Paragraph

text: ment and empty space. The discovery of what might be called ‘spatial
label: Paragraph

text: silence’—probably mainly derived from Japanese prints—was one of
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau’s chief contributions to modern Western aesthetics.
label: Paragraph

text: In this redefinition, the accepted boundary between ornament and
label: Paragraph

text: form became blurred. The classical attitude had been that ornament
label: Paragraph

text: was a supplementary form of beauty. It was the German archaeologist
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Bétticher (1806-89) who first suggested that ornament (Kunst-
label: Paragraph

text: form) was organically related to the underlying substance of the object,
label: Paragraph

text: giving the inert mechanical structure (Kernform) the semblance of
label: Paragraph

text: organic life—an idea later used by Gottfried Semper (1803-79) in his
label: Paragraph

text: book Der S#/.* Though Art Nouveau was obviously not the direct result

text: The hétels Tassel, Solvay, and Van Eetvelde [1 (see page 12), 5], all
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: each, the piano nobile consisted of a suite of reception rooms and con-
label: Paragraph

text: extended perspective . . . for evening receptions’. But this description
label: Paragraph

text: gives no idea of the sensuous and intimate language in which this social
label: Paragraph

text: function was embodied, spreading a veil over the ‘architectural-real’,
label: Paragraph

text: dissolving structure into ornament. An imaginary world—half
label: Paragraph

text: mineral, half vegetal—is created, with an air of unreality enhanced by
label: Paragraph

text: the timeless, subaqueous light filtering down from the roof.
label: Paragraph

text: Horta’s most important public building was the new Maison du
label: Paragraph

text: Peuple in Brussels of 1896-9 (demolished 1965}. He received this com-
label: Paragraph

text: mission through his domestic clients, whose social milieu and socialist
label: Paragraph

text: ideals he shared. As in the houses, the Beaux-Arts symmetry of the
label: Paragraph

text: plan is carefully undermined by asymmetrical programmatic elements.
label: Paragraph

text: The facade, though it appears to be a smooth undulating skin follow-
label: Paragraph

text: ing an irregular site boundary, is in fact a classical composition
label: Paragraph

text: arranged round a shallow exhedra. Nonetheless, because of its continu-
label: Paragraph

text: ous glazing (and in spite of its allusion to the heavily glazed Flemish
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance buildings to be found in Brussels) it must have had a
label: Paragraph

text: shocking effect when it was built.
label: Paragraph

text: If architecture was a passion for Horta, for Van de Velde (who was
label: Paragraph

text: trained as a painter) it was more the logical culmination of the ‘house-
label: Paragraph

text: hold of the arts’ (the phrase is Rumohr’s).” Starting from 1896, he

label: Paragraph

text: enced by Serrurier’s rooms. In 1895 he built a house called

text: After 1890, structural and rationalist tendencies became pro-

text: nounced in the work of Hendrick Petrus Berlage. In both the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ment used sparingly to emphasize structural junctions. Compared to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: burgher-like values.
label: Paragraph

text: In Berlage’s private houses we find the same qualities. The plan of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In Austria, the liberal, rationalist spirit was epitomized by the work

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: book, Der Stddtebau nach seinen Kiinstlerischen Grundstatzen (City
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, on the contrary, the modern city should consist of a regular,
label: Paragraph

text: open-ended street grid containing new building types such as apart-
label: Paragraph

text: ment blocks and department stores.” In his buildings, Wagner's
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism reaches its peak in the Post Office Savings Bank in Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: (1904-6). It is a rationalism, however, that does not abandon the alle-
label: Paragraph

text: gorical language of classicism but extends it. In the bank we find
label: Paragraph

text: allegorical figurative ornament: but there are also more abstract
label: Paragraph

text: metaphors, such as the redundant bolt-heads on the facade (the thin
label: Paragraph

text: marble cladding was in fact mortared to a brick wall). These, like the
label: Paragraph

text: functional glass and metal banking hall, are both symbols and manifes-
label: Paragraph

text: tations of modernity [10, 11].

text: In 1893 Wagner was appointed director of the School of Archi-

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The centre of the German Jugendstil movement was Munich, where it
label: Paragraph

text: was launched by the magazine Jugend in 1896. ‘The group of designers
label: Paragraph

text: and architects originally associated with the movement included
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Behrens (1868-1940), Richard Riemerschmid (1868-1957), and Bruno
label: Paragraph

text: Paul (1874-1968). In 1897, like the Viennese Secessionists, the Munich
label: Paragraph

text: group soon abandoned Van de Velde’s curvilinear style and began to
label: Paragraph

text: give closer attention to the Arts and Crafts movement. Under the lead-
label: Paragraph

text: ership of Riemerschmid and Paul, the Vereinigten Werkstiitten fiir
label: Caption

text: Kunst und Handwerk, founded in 1897, developed a range of semi-

text: rooms in which the furniture was simple and robust, with Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: The Art Nouveau movement was overtaken by economic and cultural
label: Paragraph

text: developments. Although it aspired to be a popular movement, its
label: Paragraph

text: hand-crafted products were only affordable by a wealthy minority
label: Paragraph

text: and it disintegrated with the decline of a certain set of bourgeois and
label: Paragraph

text: nationalist fantasies, and with the inexorable rise of machine produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and mass society. In the work of the Vienna Secession and in that
label: Paragraph

text: of Riemerschmid and Paul in Germany, we witness the Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: movement, with its stress on individuality and originality, being trans-
label: Paragraph

text: formed into repeatable forms based on vernacular and classical models.
label: Paragraph

text: But the high Art Nouveau movement left a permanent, if sub-
label: Paragraph

text: merged, legacy—the concept of an uncoded, dynamic, and instinctual
label: Paragraph

text: art, based on empathy with nature, for which it was possible to pre-
label: Paragraph

text: scribe certain principles but not to lay down any unchanging and
label: Paragraph

text: normative rules. This concept of an art without codes can be—and
label: Paragraph

text: often has been—challenged, but its power of survival in the modern
label: Paragraph

text: world can hardly be questioned.

text: Organicism versus
label: Title

text: Classicism: Chicago
label: Title

text: In a lecture entitled ‘Modern Architecture’, delivered in Schenectady
label: Paragraph

text: on g March 1884, the New York journalist and architectural critic
label: Paragraph

text: Montgomery Schuyler set out what he saw to be the problem facing
label: Paragraph

text: American architecture. Schuyler presented his argument in the form
label: Paragraph

text: of thesis and antithesis. He asserted the need for a universal culture of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture such as existed in Europe but was lacking in America due
label: Paragraph

text: to the absence of good models. The Beaux-Arts system, he said,
label: Paragraph

text: might provide the basis for such a culture, one that would inculcate
label: Paragraph

text: the qualities of ‘sobriety, measure, and discretion’, were it not for the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that it failed to produce an architecture appropriate to modern
label: Paragraph

text: life. Architecture, he says, is the most reactionary of the arts:
label: Paragraph

text: “Whereas in literature the classical rules are used, in architecture they
label: Paragraph

text: are copied . . . in architecture alone does an archaeological study pass
label: Paragraph

text: for a work of art .. . It is not the training that I am depreciating, but
label: Paragraph

text: the resting in the training as not a preparation but an attainment.’ He
label: Paragraph

text: went on to describe a confusion between language and architecture: ‘A
label: Paragraph

text: word is a conventional symbol, whereas a true architectural form is a
label: Paragraph

text: direct expression of a mechanical fact.’
label: Paragraph

text: Schuyler praised American architects, particularly those of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, for attempting to adapt architecture to such technical prob-
label: Paragraph

text: lems as the elevator and the steel frame, unhampered by too many
label: Paragraph

text: scruples about stylistic purity. Yet he felt that the problem had not been
label: Paragraph

text: fully solved. “The real structure of these towering buildings—the
label: Paragraph

text: “Chicago construction’—is a structure of steel and baked clay, and
label: Paragraph

text: when we look for the architectural expression of it, we look in vain.’
label: Paragraph

text: Such an articulated structure, ‘being the ultimate expression of a struc-
label: Paragraph

text: tural arrangement, cannot be foreseen, and the form .. . comes as a
label: Paragraph

text: surprise to the author’. Schuyler thus came out in favour of a direct and
label: Paragraph

text: expressive modern architecture. Yet he never explicitly rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts tradition. Does he think that ‘sobriety, measure, and dis-
label: Paragraph

text: cretion’ should be sacrificed on the altar of verisimilitude? That Europe
label: Paragraph

text: should be rejected? We are not told, and, in spite of his preference for
label: Paragraph

text: the second alternative, one has the impression that the first has not
label: Paragraph

text: been completely abandoned.
label: Paragraph

text: Schuyler’s writings drew attention to a conflict between the
label: Paragraph

text: architect as manipulator of a visual ‘language’ (classicist) and as expo-
label: Paragraph

text: nent of a changing technology (organicist). This can be broken down
label: Paragraph

text: into a series of further oppositions: collectivism versus individualism,
label: Paragraph

text: identity (nation) versus difference (region); the normative versus the
label: Paragraph

text: unique; representation versus expression, the recognizable versus
label: Paragraph

text: the unexpected.
label: Paragraph

text: These oppositions constantly reappeared in the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: debates of the early twentieth century. But in America, more transpar-
label: Paragraph

text: ently than in Europe, they tended to be connected with problems of
label: Paragraph

text: high national policy. It is in Chicago that this tendency manifested
label: Paragraph

text: itself most dramatically.
label: Paragraph

text: The Chicago School
label: Title

text: After the fire of 1871 and the subsequent economic depression, Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: experienced an extraordinary boom in commercial real estate. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects who flocked to the city to profit from this situation brought
label: Paragraph

text: with them a strong professional sense of mission. They saw their task
label: Paragraph

text: as the creation of a new architectural culture, believing that architec-
label: Paragraph

text: ture should express regional character and be based on modern
label: Paragraph

text: techniques. The situation in Chicago seemed to offer the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: a new synthesis of technology and aesthetics and of the creation of an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that symbolized the energy of the Mid-west.
label: Paragraph

text: The term ‘Chicago School’ was first used in 1908 by Thomas
label: Paragraph

text: Tallmadge to refer to the group of domestic architects, active between
label: Paragraph

text: 1893 and 1917, to which both he and Frank Lloyd Wright (1867-1959)
label: Paragraph

text: belonged. It was not until 1929 that it was also used for the commercial
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the 1880s and 1890s by the architectural critic Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Russell Hitchcock (1903~87) in his book Modern Architecture: Rom-
label: Paragraph

text: anticism and Reintegration. Hitchcock associated both groups of
label: Paragraph

text: architects with ‘pre-modern’ Symbolists such as Victor Horta. In the
label: Paragraph

text: 19408 he made a new distinction between a commercial and a domestic
label: Paragraph

text: phase of the school. But in contemporary usage, a complete reversal
label: Paragraph

text: has taken place and ‘Chicago School’ now generally refers to the com-
label: Paragraph

text: mercial architecture of the 1880s and 1890s, while the work of Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright and his colleagues is referred to as the ‘Prairie School’.
label: Paragraph

text: This is the terminology that will be adopted here.
label: Paragraph

text: The importance of the Chicago School was recognized during the
label: Paragraph

text: 19208 and 19308, as the writings of Hitchcock, Fiske Kimball (American
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, 1928) and Lewis Mumford (The Brown Decades, 1931)
label: Caption

text: testify. But it was given a quite new claim to modernity by the Swiss art
label: Paragraph

text: historian Sigfried Gicdion (1888-1968) in Space, Time and Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (7941), where he presented the Chicago School in Hegelian terms as a
label: Paragraph

text: stage in the progressive march of history.

label: Paragraph

text: It was Louis Sullivan’s achievement to have synthesized these two

label: Paragraph

text: the opposite fault: the similarity of functions was expressed, but the
label: Paragraph

text: building, being a mere succession of floors, was lacking in monumental
label: Paragraph

text: expression. In the Wainwright Building in St. Louis (1890-2) [23]

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In his essay entitled “The Tall Office Building Artistically Con-
label: Paragraph

text: sidered’ (1896), Sullivan claimed that the organization of the
label: Paragraph

text: Wainwright type of building into three clearly stated layers, with their
label: Paragraph

text: corresponding functions, was an application of ‘organic’ principles. In
label: Paragraph

text: order to judge the validity of this claim, it will be necessary briefly to
label: Paragraph

text: consider Sullivan’s architectural theory, as found in his two books,
label: Paragraph

text: Kindergarten Chats and The Autobiography of an Idea. More than any of
label: Paragraph

text: the other Chicago architects, Sullivan had been influenced by the New
label: Paragraph

text: England philosophical school of Transcendentalism. This philosophy,
label: Paragraph

text: whose chief spokesman had been Ralph Waldo Emerson, was largely
label: Paragraph

text: derived from German Idealism, into which Sullivan had been initiated
label: Paragraph

text: by his anarchist friend John H. Edelman. The ‘organic’ idea can be
label: Paragraph

text: traced back to the Romantic movement of around 1800—particularly to
label: Paragraph

text: such writers as Schelling and the Schlegel brothers, who believed that
label: Paragraph

text: the external form of the work of art should, as in plants and animals, be
label: Paragraph

text: the product ofan inner force or essence, rather than being mechanically
label: Paragraph

text: imposed from without, as they judged to be the case with classicism.*
label: Paragraph

text: Those architectural theorists who, in their different ways, were
label: Paragraph

text: heirs to this idea and to the concomitant notion of tectonic expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sion—such as Karl Friedrich Schinkel, Horatio Greenough, and
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc—had acknowledged that, when applied to human
label: Paragraph

text: artefacts, the concept of a ‘natural’ aesthetic had to be extended to
label: Paragraph

text: include socially derived normative values.’ Sullivan ignored this cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural factor and based his argument purely on the analogy between
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and nature. But in practice he tacitly accepted customary
label: Paragraph

text: norms. The Wainwright facade was derived from the tradition he so
label: Paragraph

text: vehemently condemned—the classical—-Baroque aesthetic enshrined
label: Paragraph

text: in Beaux-Arts teaching. In ‘correcting’ the Chicago architects’ mis-
label: Paragraph

text: taken interpretation of this tradition, he was, in fact, returning to the
label: Paragraph

text: classical principle they had discarded: the need for the facade to have a
label: Paragraph

text: tripartite hierarchy corresponding to the functional distribution of the
label: Paragraph

text: interior.
label: Paragraph

text: The Wainwright Building can certainly be called a ‘solution’ to the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of the Chicago office fagade. But its very brilliance brought
label: Paragraph

text: with it certain problems. The ‘impure’ solutions of the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: School, including Sullivan’s own Auditorium Building, had the merit
label: Paragraph

text: of presenting to the street a complex, contrapuntal texture capable of
label: Paragraph

text: being read as part of a continuous urban fabric. The Wainwright
label: Paragraph

text: Building, with its vertical emphasis and strongly marked corner
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters, isolated itself from its context and became a self-sufficient
label: Paragraph

text: entity, emphasizing the individuality of the business it both housed
label: Paragraph

text: and represented. In this, it anticipated later developments in

text: The World’s Columbian Exposition
label: Title

text: The turn towards classicism inaugurated by the Chicago World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition of 1893 was related to a number of contemporary political
label: Paragraph

text: and economic events in America. The most important of these were
label: Paragraph

text: the change from /aissez—faire to monopoly capitalism, the inaugura-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the ‘open-door’ trade policy for a country now ready to take its
label: Paragraph

text: place on the world stage, and the rise of a collectivist politics both
label: Paragraph

text: mirroring and challenging the emerging corporatism of industry and
label: Paragraph

text: finance. In The Autobiography of an Idea, Louis Sullivan was to recall
label: Paragraph

text: these developments: ‘During this period [the 1890s] there was well
label: Paragraph

text: under way the formation of mergers, corporations, and trusts in the
label: Paragraph

text: industrial world ... speculation became rampant, credit was leaving
label: Paragraph

text: terra firma... monopoly was in the air” According to Sullivan,
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham was the only architect in Chicago to catch this
label: Paragraph

text: movement, because, ‘in its tendency towards bigness, organization,
label: Paragraph

text: delegation, and intense commercialism, he sensed the reciprocal
label: Paragraph

text: workings of his own mind’. These developments were responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: sounding the death knell of the philosophy of individualism that had
label: Paragraph

text: inspired the Chicago School and been the basis of Sullivan's theory.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his own generalizing and typological propensities, Sullivan
label: Paragraph

text: resisted the emerging tendency towards collectivism, standardization,
label: Paragraph

text: and massification that Burnham welcomed so avidly.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The World’s Fair initiated a wave of classical architecture in America.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Social reform and the home
label: Title

text: The reaction of intellectuals against the excesses of uncontrolled capi-
label: Paragraph

text: talism in 1880s America is represented by two Utopian texts: Henry
label: Paragraph

text: George’s Progress and Poverty (1880), which proposed the confiscation
label: Paragraph

text: of all yield from increased land value, and Edward Bellamy’s novel
label: Paragraph

text: Looking Backward (1888), which described a future society based on a
label: Paragraph

text: perfected industrial system, in which there was no longer any space
label: Paragraph

text: between freedom and total political control (see pages 220-2: ‘Systems
label: Title

text: theory’). A third text—Thorstein Veblen's Theory of the Leisure Class
label: Paragraph

text: (1899)—is of particular interest, not only because Veblen taught at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Chicago in the 1890s, but also because his book advanced
label: Paragraph

text: the theory that there was a conflict in capitalism between the produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of money and the production of goods.”
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago was the centre of a vigorous social reform movement
label: Paragraph

text: which reflected this anti-/aissez-faire mood. Whereas the Transcen-
label: Paragraph

text: dentalists had rejected the city as a corrupting influence, the Chicago
label: Paragraph

text: reformists saw it as an essential instrument of industrialization, but
label: Paragraph

text: one that needed to be domesticated. The Department of Social
label: Paragraph

text: Sciences and Anthropology, which opened in 1892 in the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago under the leadership of Albion Small, became an important
label: Paragraph

text: centre of urban sociology, its wide influence continuing into the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: The department and the institutions connected with it, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Household Science at the University of Illinois,
label: Caption

text: focused their attention on the nuclear family and the individual home
label: Paragraph

text: in the belief that the reform of the domestic environment was the nec-
label: Paragraph

text: essary first step in the reform of society as a whole. Thus, the design
label: Paragraph

text: and equipment of the home became one of the key elements in a
label: Paragraph

text: radical and wide-ranging social and political agenda."*
label: Paragraph

text: The problem of the home was addressed at two levels. Hull House,
label: Paragraph

text: founded by Jane Addams in 1897, and the numerous settlement houses
label: Paragraph

text: that it helped to set up, worked at the grass-roots level, providing
label: Paragraph

text: domestic education to immigrant workers living in slum conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the essential ingredients of this education was training in the
label: Paragraph

text: crafts, which was organized by the Chicago Arts and Crafts Society,
label: Paragraph

text: also based at Hull House. Classes and exhibitions in cabinet-making,
label: Paragraph

text: bookmaking, weaving, and pottery were set up. Some small workshops
label: Paragraph

text: were founded, but much of the furniture was made by commercial
label: Paragraph

text: manufacturers, sometimes, but not always, under the supervision of
label: Paragraph

text: outside designers. The work was promoted by mass-circulation maga-
label: Paragraph

text: zines like the Ladies’ Home Journal and The House Beautiful and sold by
label: Paragraph

text: mail order. Low income groups were targeted, and the furniture was
label: Paragraph

text: mass produced. In design, it was somewhat heavier and simpler than
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary Arts and Crafts furniture in England and Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: tending towards the geometrical forms in the work of I loffmann and
label: Paragraph

text: Mackintosh, but without their hand-crafted refinement.
label: Paragraph

text: Ata more theoretical level, the problem of the modern home was
label: Paragraph

text: analysed in the department of Social Sciences and the closely affiliated
label: Paragraph

text: Home Economies group. ‘Vhis nationwide movement had its epicentre
label: Paragraph

text: in Chicago and one of its leading figures, Marion Talbot, taught at the
label: Paragraph

text: Department of Social Sciences. The movement was strongly feminist
label: Paragraph

text: and sought to revolutionize the position of women, both in the home
label: Paragraph

text: and in society. According to the [Tome Economics group there was an
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and inventions such as the telephone, electric light, and new means of
label: Paragraph

text: transport. The home should be organized according to Frederick
label: Paragraph

text: Winslow Taylor’s principle of scientific management. The more
label: Paragraph

text: radical members of the group, like the Marxist Charlotte Perkins
label: Paragraph

text: Gillman, argued against the nuclear house and advocated the social-
label: Paragraph

text: ization of eating, cleaning, and entertainment in serviced apartment
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, but generally the group accepted the nuclear house.
label: Paragraph

text: In matters of design the Home Economics group followed William
label: Paragraph

text: Morris in his belief that the house should contain nothing but useful
label: Paragraph

text: and beautiful objects. But they also believed in mass production and
label: Paragraph

text: the use of new, smooth materials, invoking the railroad-car buffet and
label: Paragraph

text: the laboratory as models for the design of kitchens, and stressing the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: word ‘Euthenics’ to describe the science of the controlled environ-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, a word evidently intended to rhyme with Eugenics. They called
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: munity.’* In this, their views were not unlike those of the City
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright and the Prairie School
label: Title

text: The Prairie School was a closely knit group of young Chicago archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects continuing to design houses in the organicist tradition under the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Hull House and the Arts and Crafts Society. Some of the original
label: Caption

text: group later reverted to eclecticism—notably Howard Van Doren Shaw
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Edwin Lutyens in its simultaneous allegiance to the Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: and to eclectic classicism."*
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tectural League of America around 1901.'* This concept was promoted
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: have the effect of compressing the vertical dimension, producing a
label: Paragraph

text: primitive, cave-like sensation [31].
label: Paragraph

text: The system of ornament consists of dark-stained wood trim, recall-
label: Paragraph

text: ing that of Mackintosh and Hoffmann. Electric light and ventilation
label: Paragraph

text: fittings are absorbed into the general ornamental unity. ‘Art’ still dom-
label: Paragraph

text: inates, but it is now produced by the machine, not by the craftsman,
label: Paragraph

text: and is totally controlled by the architect working at his drawing-board
label: Paragraph

text: [32]: “The machine . . . has placed in artist hands the means of
label: Paragraph

text: idealizing the true nature of wood . . . without waste, within reach of
label: Paragraph

text: all.”
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, Wright came early on to the conclusion that mass produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion was necessary if good design was to be democratically enjoyed. In
label: Paragraph

text: rgor he gave a lecture at Hull House entitled “The Art and Craft of the
label: Paragraph

text: Machine’ in which he argued that the alienation of the craftsman due
label: Paragraph

text: to machine production would be outweighed by the artist’s ability to
label: Paragraph

text: create beauty with the machine—an anti-Ruskinian argument that
label: Paragraph

text: would soon be taken up within the Deutscher Werkbund in its support
label: Paragraph

text: of machine work as opposed to handwork. This philosophy was com-
label: Paragraph

text: pletely consistent with Wright’s search for universal laws of design,
label: Paragraph

text: with its privileging of the artist over the craftsman.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet Wright’s position on industrialization was ultimately ambiva-
label: Paragraph

text: lent. It was poised between an endorsement of ‘that greatest of
label: Paragraph

text: machines’, as he called the industrial city, and a nostalgic image of the
label: Paragraph

text: American suburb as a new Arcadia uncontaminated by industrialism.
label: Paragraph

text: This conflict was reflected in his daily life, divided between his radical
label: Paragraph

text: friends at Hull House and the suburb of Oak Park where he practised
label: Paragraph

text: and lived with his young family, and where his neighbours were the
label: Paragraph

text: practical-minded businessmen who commissioned his houses.”° This
label: Paragraph

text: enormously creative and influential phase of Wright’s life came to an
label: Paragraph

text: abrupt end when in 1909, at the age of 42, he abandoned Oak Park,

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: nity. Reviving dreams of the frontier, he sought, more passionately
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: architecture of rural innocence.
label: Paragraph

text: It was the formal skill with which Wright deployed an abstract and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tects when his work was published in Germany by Wasmuth in 1910, at
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Culture and
label: Title

text: Industry: Germany
label: Title

text: The international reform movement in architecture and the industrial
label: Title

text: arts was accompanied in Germany by special historical circumstances.
label: Paragraph

text: In the German-speaking world, a self-image had begun to take shape
label: Paragraph

text: in the second half of the eighteenth century in opposition to French
label: Paragraph

text: cultural hegemony and Enlightenment universalism. The conscious-
label: Paragraph

text: ness of a specifically German Ku/tur, as distinct from French-derived
label: Paragraph

text: Zivilisation, was reinforced during the Napoleonic wars. The effect of
label: Paragraph

text: this was to intensify the search for cultural identity, but at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time to act as a powerful incentive to modernization. Romanticism and
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalism coexisted, sometimes in mutual reinforcement, some-
label: Paragraph

text: times in opposition. Modernization increased its pace after the
label: Paragraph

text: unification of Germany’s many states into the German Empire in 1871.
label: Paragraph

text: But by the 1890s there was already widespread disappointment with its
label: Paragraph

text: cultural results, and the beginning of an anti-liberal, anti-positivist
label: Paragraph

text: backlash. This tendency mirrored similar tendencies in Europe as a
label: Paragraph

text: whole, but in Germany it brought to the surface a latent ideology of the
label: Paragraph

text: Volk According to the writer Julius Langbehn (1851-1907) modern
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, especially that of America, was without roots. In his best-
label: Paragraph

text: selling book Rembrandt als Erzieher (Rembrandt as Educator, Leipzig,
label: Caption

text: 1903), he argued for a return to the rooted culture of the German Vo/f,
label: Paragraph

text: the spirit of which he saw as embodied in the paintings of Rembrandt.
label: Paragraph

text: The social philosopher Ferdinand Ténnies (1856-1936), in his book
label: Paragraph

text: Gemeinschaft und Gesellschaft (roughly: Community and Society,
label: Paragraph

text: Leipzig, 1887), drew attention to the ancient German forms of associa-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, which were being replaced by modern industrial forms of
label: Paragraph

text: association or ‘companies’.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, the movement for artistic reform in Germany was, from the
label: Paragraph

text: start, deeply involved in the question of national identity. Those par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticipating in the movement were caught between a desire to return to
label: Paragraph

text: their pre-industrial roots and an equally strong impulse towards
label: Paragraph

text: modernization as the necessary condition of competing commercially
label: Paragraph

text: with the Western nations.
label: Paragraph

text: The Deutscher Werkbund
label: Title

text: At the beginning of the twentieth century in Germany, the chief agent
label: Paragraph

text: of artistic and cultural reform was the Deutscher Werkbund, which
label: Paragraph

text: grew out of the German Arts and Crafts (Kunstgewerbe) movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Many local reform groups had emerged since the onset of the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts movement in the late 1890s, including Alfred Lichtwark’s Art
label: Paragraph

text: Education Movement (1897), Ferdinand Avenarius’s Diirerbund
label: Paragraph

text: (1902), and the Bund Heimatschutz (1904).? In addition, a number of
label: Paragraph

text: workshops modelled on the English guilds had been founded, the
label: Paragraph

text: most successful of which were the Munich-based Vereinigten Werk-
label: Paragraph

text: stitte (see page 62) and the Dresdner Werkstitte, both of which, unlike
label: Paragraph

text: their English counterparts, were making semi-mass-produced furni-
label: Paragraph

text: ture from their inception.
label: Paragraph

text: The Deutscher Werkbund was founded in Munich in 1907 to con-
label: Paragraph

text: solidate these separate initiatives and accelerate the integration of art
label: Paragraph

text: and industry at a national level. The chief moving spirits behind its
label: Paragraph

text: foundation were the Christian Socialist politician Friedrich Naumann
label: Paragraph

text: (1860-1919), the director of the Dresdner Werkstiatte Karl Schmidt,
label: Paragraph

text: and the architect-bureaucrat Hermann Muthesius (1861-1927).
label: Paragraph

text: Initially 12 architects and 12 companies were invited to join. The archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tects included Peter Behrens (1868-1940), Theodor Fischer
label: Paragraph

text: (1862-1938), Josef Hoffmann, Joseph Maria Olbrich, Paul Schultze-
label: Paragraph

text: Naumburg (1869-1949), and Fritz Schumacher (1869-1947). Most of
label: Paragraph

text: the companies were manufacturers of domestic furniture and equip-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, but two printers, a type founder, and a publisher were also
label: Paragraph

text: included. All these firms withdrew from the existing conservative and
label: Paragraph

text: commercially motivated Alliance for German Applied Arts to join the
label: Paragraph

text: new organization and in so doing committed themselves to working
label: Paragraph

text: with named architects.
label: Paragraph

text: The Werkbund’s orientation towards high-quality goods for mass
label: Paragraph

text: consumption is clear from a speech given by Naumann in 1906: ‘Many
label: Paragraph

text: people do not have the money to hire artists, and, consequently, many
label: Paragraph

text: products are going to be mass produced; for this great problem, the
label: Paragraph

text: only solution is to infuse mass-production with meaning and spirit by
label: Paragraph

text: artistic means.” Speaking at the inaugural meeting of the Werkbund in
label: Paragraph

text: Munich, Fritz Schumacher, professor of architecture at the Dresden
label: Caption

text: Technische Hochschule and director of a highly successful Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts exhibition in Dresden in 1906, stressed the need to bridge the
label: Paragraph

text: gap between artists and producers that had developed with machine
label: Paragraph

text: production:
label: Title

text: The time has come when Germany should cease to look on the artist as a man
label: Paragraph

text: who .. . follows his inclination, and rather see him as one of the important
label: Paragraph

text: powers for the ennobling of work and therefore for the ennobling of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: life of the nation, and to make it victorious in the competition among peoples
label: Paragraph

text: ... there is in aesthetic power a higher economic value.*
label: Paragraph

text: Despite this well-defined programme, the membership of the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund represented a wide range of opinion. The organization's
label: Paragraph

text: main areas of activity were: general propaganda (publishing, exhibi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, congresses); the education of the consumer (lectures, window
label: Paragraph

text: dressing competitions, and so on); and the reform of product design
label: Paragraph

text: (for example, persuading industrialists to employ artists}.
label: Paragraph

text: Form or Gestalt
label: Title

text: The need to assimilate the machine to the artistic principles of the Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts movement entailed a reconceptualization of the role of the
label: Paragraph

text: artist. Morris’s conception of the artist-craftsman as someone physi-
label: Paragraph

text: cally involved with materials and functions gave way to that of the artist
label: Paragraph

text: as ‘form giver’. The new concept was put forward at the Werkbund
label: Paragraph

text: congress of 1908 by the sculptor Rudolf Bosselt, and reaffirmed by
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius in 1911.° Both asserted that, in the design of machine prod-
label: Paragraph

text: ucts, ‘form’ or Gestalt’ should take precedence over function, material,
label: Paragraph

text: and technique, which had been stressed by the Arts and Crafts and
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil movements. Curiously enough, this idea did not originate in
label: Paragraph

text: the context of the debate on art and industry, but in the field of aesthet-
label: Paragraph

text: ics. It was the product of a century-long history of aesthetic thought,
label: Paragraph

text: beginning with Immanuel Kant’s isolation of art as an autonomous
label: Paragraph

text: system, and culminating in the theory of ‘pure visibility’ (Sicbrbarkeit)
label: Paragraph

text: propounded by the philosopher of aesthetics Conrad Fiedler.
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius and the notion of type
label: Title

text: Closely connected with the idea of Gestalt was Muthesius’s concept of
label: Paragraph

text: Typisierung (typification)—a word he coined to denote the establish-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of standard or typical forms.’ His argument was the apparently
label: Paragraph

text: trivial one that mass production entails standardization. But, relying
label: Paragraph

text: on the ambiguity inherent in the word ‘type’, Muthesius conflated a
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic notion of standardization with the idea of the ‘type’ as a
label: Paragraph

text: Platonic universal. Only through typification, he said, ‘can architecture
label: Paragraph

text: recover that universal significance which was characteristic of it in
label: Paragraph

text: times of harmonious culture’.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius’s concept of a unified culture was an attack on /aissez-
label: Paragraph

text: faire capitalism, though not on monopoly capitalism. For him, and for
label: Paragraph

text: many within the Werkbund who shared his views, the degeneration of
label: Paragraph

text: modern taste was due not, as Ruskin had thought, to the machine as
label: Paragraph

text: such, but to the cultural disorder caused by the operation of the
label: Paragraph

text: market, and the destabilizing effect of fashion. If the middle-man who
label: Paragraph

text: manipulated the market could be eliminated it would be possible to
label: Paragraph

text: recover the direct relationship between producer and consumer and
label: Paragraph

text: between technique and culture, that had existed in pre-capitalist soci-
label: Paragraph

text: eties. Muthesius foresaw the emergence of large factories for the
label: Paragraph

text: production of consumer goods similar to the trusts and cartels that
label: Paragraph

text: were becoming increasingly characteristic of German heavy industry.
label: Paragraph

text: These firms, producing goods of standardized artistic quality, would be
label: Paragraph

text: able to dominate the market and act as the sole arbiters of taste, operat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing as the modern equivalent of the medieval guilds.’
label: Paragraph

text: When Muthesius presented his notion of Typisierung at the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund congress of rg14 at Cologne it was strongly criticized by a
label: Paragraph

text: group of artists, architects, and critics which included Van de Velde,
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut (1880-1938) and Walter Gropius (1883-1969). Van de
label: Paragraph

text: Velde, though a passionate disciple of William Morris, did not ques-
label: Paragraph

text: tion the need for machine production, nor did he disagree with the
label: Paragraph

text: notion of a unified culture. But he disagreed with the bureaucratic
label: Paragraph

text: methods proposed by Muthesius. For him and his supporters, culture
label: Paragraph

text: could not be created by the imposition of typical forms. High artistic
label: Paragraph

text: quality depended on the freedom of the individual artist. Fixed types
label: Paragraph

text: did indeed emerge in all artistic cultures, but they were the end-prod-
label: Paragraph

text: ucts of an evolutionary process of artistic development, not its initial
label: Paragraph

text: condition. Muthesius had simply reversed the order of cause and
label: Paragraph

text: effect. This celebrated conflict has usually been interpreted as a battle
label: Paragraph

text: between the avant-garde supporters of a new machine culture and the
label: Paragraph

text: regressive supporters of an outdated handicraft tradition. The truth is
label: Paragraph

text: more complex, and to understand the situation it is necessary to disen-
label: Paragraph

text: tangle the confusion that reigned at the time as to the status of the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘artist’ in the modern industrial arts.
label: Paragraph

text: The debate between Van de Velde and Muthesius cannot be seen
label: Paragraph

text: merely as the conflict between handicraft and the machine (though it
label: Paragraph

text: was this as well) since the ambiguous figure of the ‘artist’ appears as
label: Paragraph

text: chief protagonist on both sides. Both groups believed that, under con-
label: Paragraph

text: ditions of machine production, division of labour had separated
label: Paragraph

text: technique from art and that it was necessary to reintroduce the artist
label: Paragraph

text: into the production process. They differed, however, in their interpreta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of role that the artist would now play. Insofar as he saw the artist as
label: Paragraph

text: a specialist in ‘pure form’, divorced from the mechanics of craft (now the
label: Paragraph

text: domain of the machine), Muthesius’s position seems ‘progressive’,
label: Paragraph

text: seeking to adapt the artist to the abstract processes of capitalism. But
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde’s concept of the evolutionary process of style formation
label: Paragraph

text: was more compatible with the conditions of market capitalism, and in
label: Paragraph

text: that sense more ‘modern’ than Muthesius’s bureaucratic model. To what
label: Paragraph

text: extent Van de Velde, with his strongly held socialist views, grasped the
label: Paragraph

text: connection between the artistic freedom he was proposing and the mar-
label: Paragraph

text: ketplace is an intriguing question, but the connection is clearly reflected
label: Paragraph

text: in the writings of his patron and supporter, Karl Ernst Osthaus.”
label: Paragraph

text: Originally Muthesius had also held to this concept of the individu-
label: Paragraph

text: alistic artist. For example, he had been in favour of the law of 1907
label: Paragraph

text: which gave the applied artist the copyright protection that was already
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed by the fine artist.!’ But some time between 1907 and 1910 he
label: Paragraph

text: seems to have moved towards the idea that the artist should not seek
label: Paragraph

text: originality, but should be the conduit for universal aesthetic laws, a view
label: Paragraph

text: that was in line with the prevalent neo-Kantian aesthetic philosophy.
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius now argued that there was a kinship between the law-like
label: Paragraph

text: stability and anonymity of the classical and vernacular traditions on the
label: Paragraph

text: one hand, and the repetitiveness, regularity, and simplicity of machined
label: Paragraph

text: forms on the other. Machined forms were the modern, historical
label: Paragraph

text: instance of a universal law. Though this idea did not exclude the artist,
label: Paragraph

text: it did demand that the personality of the artist should be controlled."
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius sought to implement these ideas by creating an organi-
label: Paragraph

text: zational framework within which future artists would have to work,
label: Paragraph

text: thus reverting to archaic processes similar to those that Karl Friedrich
label: Paragraph

text: Schinkel had adopted when commissioned to ‘normalize’ the rural
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Prussia a century earlier. In Muthesius, therefore, we
label: Paragraph

text: see the fusion of two ideologies, the one bureaucratic and nationalistic,
label: Paragraph

text: the other classicizing and normative. Though it is difficult to say at
label: Paragraph

text: what level these ideologies are, in fact, connected, they appear to have
label: Paragraph

text: been inseparable within the context of architectural discourse in the
label: Paragraph

text: years leading up to the First World War in Germany. It was a combina-
label: Paragraph

text: tion that took a particularly explosive form in Germany, but it was also
label: Paragraph

text: present, in differing regional forms, in America, England, and France.
label: Paragraph

text: Style and ideology
label: Title

text: Another aspect of the battle between Muthesius’s concept of type and
label: Paragraph

text: the spontaneity demanded by Van de Velde must now be addressed.
label: Paragraph

text: The standardization required by machine production was seen to rec-
label: Paragraph

text: oncile modernity with classical humanism. But the demand for the
label: Paragraph

text: freedom of the artist was also associated with a Nietzschian, Dionysian,
label: Paragraph

text: anarchistic urge not to try to tame the disorder of modernity but to
label: Paragraph

text: plunge into its terrifying and nihilistic stream. These different attitudes
label: Paragraph

text: correspond to two groups of architects. Among the classicizing group,
label: Paragraph

text: two will be discussed here—Heinrich Tessenow (1876-1950) and Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens—and their work will be compared to that of the young Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius, who was poised between the two groups. Discussion of the
label: Paragraph

text: opposite camp, the Expressionists, belongs to a later chapter.
label: Paragraph

text: Heinrich Tessenow
label: Title

text: One of Heinrich Tessenow’s major concerns was mass housing and the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of repetition. He studied this issue in the context of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: suggests an idyllic
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: English Garden City movement, which had had a great influence on
label: Paragraph

text: the German Arts and Crafts. Most of the leading architects of the day
label: Paragraph

text: were similarly involved. Behrens, Riemerschmid, Muthesius, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: Tessenow, designed groups of houses for Karl Schmidt’s workers’
label: Paragraph

text: settlement of Hellerau, just outside Dresden. These architects were
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the medieval models advocated by Camillo Sitte (see
label: Paragraph

text: page 28) and continued by the Garden City movement. But this influ-
label: Paragraph

text: ence was modified by that of Paul Mebes, whose popular book Um
label: Paragraph

text: z800, which appeared in 1905, advocated a return to the classical
label: Paragraph

text: Biedermeier tradition of the early nineteenth century as the last
label: Paragraph

text: instance of a unified German culture. As we have seen, a similar shift
label: Paragraph

text: towards the classical occurred in the furniture designed by the Vere-
label: Paragraph

text: inigten Werkstitte (see page 58). This tendency was not restricted to
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. For example, in the last years of the Arts and Crafts move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment in England, there was a similar return to what might be called the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘classical vernacular’ of the eighteenth century (commonly known as
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Georgian’), which was seen to represent ‘form’ and ‘proportion’ as
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to ‘detail’ (though, characteristically, this development was
label: Paragraph

text: not theorized to the extent that it was in Germany).
label: Paragraph

text: Tessenow’s housing projects were supported by a social theory that
label: Paragraph

text: romanticized the petite bourgeoisie as the foundation of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: German social order, and his fastidious drawings conjure up a lost
label: Paragraph

text: world of neat Biedermeier innocence. He visualized small towns of
label: Paragraph

text: between 20,000 and 60,000 inhabitants, with a handicraft industry
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating a maximum of ten artisans per workshop. Tessenow’s
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of industrial civilization was hardly less extreme than Ruskin’s,
label: Paragraph

text: though his preference for classical forms is very un-Ruskinian [34].
label: Paragraph

text: Besides housing, Tessenow built the main ‘cultural’ building in
label: Paragraph

text: Hellerau—Jaques Dalcroze’s school of eurhythmics (tg11-12) [35]. The
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Behrens
label: Title

text: Behrens began as a painter associated with the Munich Secession of
label: Paragraph

text: 1893. He was a founding member of the Darmstadt artists’ colony
label: Paragraph

text: where in 1901 he built the only house not designed by Olbrich (see
label: Paragraph

text: page 30). His approach to art and architecture was deeply tinged with
label: Paragraph

text: the Symbolism that characterized the German secessionist move-
label: Paragraph

text: ments. His mystical leanings had already shown themselves when he
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: cal reform in Germany. One of the crucial turning points in Behrens’s

text: and Crafts at Diisseldorf between 1903 and 1907, where he was influ-

label: Paragraph

text: In 1907, outlining the programme of the Diisseldorf School, he wrote:
