text: From 1905 onwards, Behrens designed a number of buildings in a
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical Tuscan Romanesque style. These included a crematorium
label: Paragraph

text: at Hagen (1905) and the Allgemeine Elektricitits-Gesellschaft (AEG)
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion for the Shipbuilding Exposition in Berlin (1908) [37], as well
label: Paragraph

text: as a series of neoclassical villas such as the Cuno House at Hagen-
label: Paragraph

text: Eppenhausen (1908-9) and the Wiegand House in Berlin (1911). But
label: Paragraph

text: the climax of this classical phase of Behrens’s career was his design for
label: Paragraph

text: the huge AEG Turbine Factory in Berlin (1908-9). Behrens was
label: Paragraph

text: appointed design consultant for the electrical giant in 1907 and was
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for all AEG’s design work, including logos, consumer
label: Paragraph

text: products, and buildings—a perfect example of Muthesius’s ideal of col-
label: Paragraph

text: laboration between the artist and big industry [38]. The Turbine
label: Caption

text: Factory [39], designed in collaboration with the engineer Karl Bern-
label: Paragraph

text: hard, was the first and the most symbolically loaded of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial buildings that Behrens was to build on AEG’s huge Berlin-
label: Paragraph

text: Moabit site between 1908 and 1912. Behrens’s buildings for AEG
label: Caption

text: reflect his faith in the ennobling effect of art on technology. He
label: Paragraph

text: claimed that the architecture of the machine age should be based on
label: Paragraph

text: classicism—that in an age of speed the only appropriate buildings
label: Paragraph

text: would be those with forms as distinct as possible, with quict, flush
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces.'* His critics pointed out that his own buildings reflected

label: Paragraph

text: immobility and mass rather than speed,” and indeed it seems that
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens was suggesting a form of resistance to, rather than an accep-
label: Paragraph

text: tance of, the modern metropolis—that metropolis which for the
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher and sociologist Georg Simmel (1858-1918) was character-
label: Paragraph

text: ized by ‘the intensification of nervous stimuli resulting from a rapid and
label: Paragraph

text: uninterrupted succession of impressions’.”°
label: Paragraph

text: Certainly, another Symbolism than that of the fleeting and
label: Paragraph

text: ephemeral is at work in the Turbine Factory. Here Behrens set out to
label: Paragraph

text: spiritualize the power of modern industry in terms of an eternal classi-
label: Paragraph

text: cism. The basic metaphor at work is the factory as Greek temple. The
label: Paragraph

text: corner site makes possible a diagonal approach allowing the observer to
label: Paragraph

text: view front and side elevations simultaneously, as in the case of the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthenon. The metaphor is elaborated with great plastic skill.
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens establishes two simultaneous systems, an outer columnar one,
label: Paragraph

text: and an inner one of surface. An ‘order’ of steel stanchions, resting on
label: Paragraph

text: giant hinges [40], takes the place of the temple colonnade, in a direct
label: Paragraph

text: metonymic displacement. The continuous side glazing, made opaque
label: Paragraph

text: by a close pattern of glazing bars [33 (see page 56)], is inclined to the
label: Paragraph

text: same slope as the inner face of the stanchions, giving a rather Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: effect. This is continued in the corner buttresses, their mass further
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized by deep horizontal striations [41]. These buttresses create
label: Paragraph

text: an effect of classical mass and stability but in fact they are only thin
label: Paragraph

text: membranes and perform no structural role whatever. Moreover, even
label: Paragraph

text: their apparent structural role is undermined by the projecting central
label: Paragraph

text: window, which appears to be supporting the pediment. Because of this

text: Walter Gropius and the Fagus Factory
label: Title

text: Gropius had worked for Behrens between 1g10 and 1911 and had
label: Paragraph

text: absorbed many of his ideas, but he was 15 years younger—a gap large
label: Paragraph

text: enough to explain certain ideological differences. For example he was
label: Paragraph

text: more concerned than Behrens with the social implications of machine
label: Paragraph

text: production, realizing that it meant the irretrievable separation of artis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic conceptualization and the production process, and that the
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between the craftsman and his own products would hence-
label: Paragraph

text: forth be that of consumer not producer. In an address entitled ‘Kunst
label: Paragraph

text: und Industriecbau’ given at the Volkwang Museum at Hagen in igi,
label: Caption

text: Gropius tried to suggest a socially acceptable solution to this problem:
label: Paragraph

text: Work must be established in palaces that give the workman, now a slave to
label: Paragraph

text: industrial labour, not only light, air, and hygiene, but also an indication of the
label: Paragraph

text: great common idea that drives everything. Only then can the individual
label: Paragraph

text: submit to the impersonal without losing the joy of working together for that
label: Paragraph

text: common good previously unattainable by a single individual.
label: Paragraph

text: In exchange for being alienated from the end product of their work,
label: Paragraph

text: workers, as consumers, are offered a transcendental collective experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ence. This idea, which had been aired a few years earlier by Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright (see page 53) was to be given a philosophically more
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated formulation by the architect and critic Adolf Behne in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1920s.°? But through the mists of a rather confused rhetoric one
label: Paragraph

text: glimpses the troubled social Utopianism that was to throw Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: into the camp of the anti-technological Expressionists at the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: First World War. For the moment, however, Gropius did not doubt
label: Paragraph

text: that the machine could be spiritualized by means of art, and advocated
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture of technical rationalism, even presenting to Emil
label: Paragraph

text: Rathenau, director of AEG,” a memorandum on the rationalization
label: Paragraph

text: of the housing industry.”*
label: Paragraph

text: Why, then, was Gropius the most implacable of all Muthesi
label: Paragraph

text: critics at the Cologne congress? The answer must lic in the ambiguous
label: Paragraph

text: nature of the concept of ‘totalization’ to which both he and Muthesius
label: Paragraph

text: subscribed. Both believed that the artist (or the architect-as-artist) was
label: Paragraph

text: now an intellectual charged with the task of inventing the forms of the
label: Paragraph

text: machine age, considered as a cultural totality. But for Gropius it was
label: Paragraph

text: precisely this totalizing, legislative, quasi-ethical role that demanded
label: Paragraph

text: that the artist should remain free of political interference. Only the
label: Paragraph

text: best and the most original ideas would be worthy of mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: By
label: Title

text: reproduction. In this, Gropius was at one with Van de Velde. He
label: Paragraph

text: violently rejected the idea of the control of artistic conceptualization by
label: Paragraph

text: the state bureaucracy or its proxy, big business, which was being
label: Paragraph

text: promoted by Muthesius. But at the level of theory Gropius’s position
label: Paragraph

text: was no different from that of Behrens in its postulation of two realms,
label: Paragraph

text: one of which—nature-technology—would be transfigured by the
label: Paragraph

text: other—spirit (Geiss).
label: Paragraph

text: In Gropius’s architecture, however, there is something new, and we
label: Paragraph

text: can get some idea of it if we compare his Fagus Factory (1911-12) [42,
label: Paragraph

text: 43] at Alfeld an der Leine, built in collaboration with Adolf Meyer
label: Caption

text: (1881-1929), with Behrens’s Turbine Factory. Much of the difference
label: Paragraph

text: between the two buildings can be attributed to their radically different
label: Paragraph

text: programmes. Gropius and Meyer's small, provincial shoe-last
label: Caption

text: factory—or rather its administrative wing, which was the only part of
label: Paragraph

text: the factory complex over which the architects had full control—could
label: Paragraph

text: hardly be said to invoke the world-historical themes of Behrens’s
label: Paragraph

text: factory, built in the nation’s capital for one of Germany’s most impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant cartels. Yet it was precisely the Fagus Factory’s modesty and lack of
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic charge that enabled Gropius to follow his more down-to-
label: Paragraph

text: earth agenda and to produce a work which would come to be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: prophetic of the ‘objective’ (Sachlich) Modern Movement of the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: Not that the building lacks optical tricks. But it no longer makes
label: Paragraph

text: any of Behrens’s grandiose symbolic claims. Gropius starts with
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens’s projecting bay window and recessed, tilted masonry as his
label: Paragraph

text: main motifs, but transforms them. The tilt is now, it seems, a prag-
label: Paragraph

text: matic (though probably expensive) solution, by means of which the
label: Paragraph

text: brick piers can appear to be recessed without the glazing unit having to
label: Paragraph

text: be cantilevered out at its sill. Whereas Behrens rhetoricizes his repeat-
label: Paragraph

text: ing columns, giving them maximum corporeality to create the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: classical monumentality, Gropius tries to make his necessarily massive
label: Paragraph

text: brick piers disappear, so that the main fagade of his building looks as if
label: Paragraph

text: it is made entirely of glass. Whereas Behrens strengthens his corners
label: Paragraph

text: with illusionistic buttresses, Gropius voids his with real transparency.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Behrens impressionistically rounds his corners, Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: sharpens his with the precision of a surgeon’s knife-cut. Finally,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the Turbine Factory abounds in overt classical references, the
label: Paragraph

text: classicism of the Fagus Factory is discreet and abstract—a matter of
label: Paragraph

text: geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: But though the Fagus Factory can thus be read off against the
label: Paragraph

text: Turbine Factory, it is not simply a mannerist inversion; it has its own
label: Paragraph

text: agenda. Its illusionism, though still owing something to Behrens, is a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of bringing out the transcendent qualities of materials—partic-
label: Paragraph

text: ularly glass with its mystical connotations (see the discussion of glass
label: Paragraph

text: symbolism on page 92)—rather than working against the nature of
label: Paragraph

text: materials as Behrens often did. In this Gropius was truer to the ‘func-
label: Paragraph

text: tional’ tradition of Jugendstil, even though he jettisoned most (if not
label: Paragraph

text: all) of its craftsman-like individualism. In the Fagus factory, material-
label: Paragraph

text: ity and form are synthesized in a new way—a way that seems to show
label: Paragraph

text: the influence of the American factories that Gropius had illustrated

text: Adolf Loos 1900—30
label: Title

text: Adolf Loos (1870-1933) occupies a unique place in the history of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. A maverick who refused to join any ‘club’, he was
label: Paragraph

text: not only a powerful thinker able to expose the contradictions of con-
label: Paragraph

text: temporary theory but an architect whose work, though small in output,
label: Paragraph

text: was provocative and highly original. His influence on the succeeding
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architects, particularly Le Corbusier, was enormous, and
label: Paragraph

text: his ideas have, through successive reinterpretations, maintained their
label: Paragraph

text: relevance to the present day.
label: Paragraph

text: The son ofa stonemason, Loos was born in Brno, Moravia (at the time part
label: Paragraph

text: of the Austro-Hungarian empire, now in the Czech Republic) and studied at
label: Paragraph

text: the Imperial State Technical College in Vienna, and the Dresden College of
label: Paragraph

text: technology. In 1893 he travelled to America, where his uncle had emigrated,
label: Paragraph

text: ng the Columbia World’s Fair and eventually starting a small practice in
label: Paragraph

text: New York before returning to Austria in 1896. As a result of this experience,
label: Paragraph

text: he was to retain a lifelong admiration for Anglo-American culture.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he belonged to the same generation as the main figures of
label: Paragraph

text: the Art Nouveau and Jugendstil movements, Loos reacted strongly
label: Paragraph

text: against their attempt to replace Beaux-Arts eclecticism with what he
label: Paragraph

text: saw as a superficial system of ornament. He was not, of course, alone in
label: Paragraph

text: his rejection of Jugendstil and its ideology of the Gesamrkunstwerk, In
label: Paragraph

text: Germany by 1902, as we have seen, designers like Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Riemerschmid and Bruno Paul had abandoned this style, and in
label: Paragraph

text: Austria Josef Hoffmann, the founder of the Wiener Werkstitte, had
label: Paragraph

text: drastically simplified the Secessionist vocabulary. But Loos’s critique
label: Paragraph

text: was more fundamental than theirs; it was based on a rejection of the
label: Paragraph

text: very concept of ‘art’ when applied to the design of objects for everyday
label: Paragraph

text: use. Whereas Van de Velde and the Jugendstil movement had wanted
label: Paragraph

text: to eliminate the distinction between the craftsman and the artist, Loos
label: Paragraph

text: saw the split between them as irreversible. Far from believing in a
label: Paragraph

text: unified culture in which the craftsman and the artist would be
label: Paragraph

text: reunited, he readily accepted the distinction between the objects of
label: Paragraph

text: everyday life and imaginative works of art. But for Loos that distinc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion was not based on the division of hand-work and machine-work or
label: Paragraph

text: of mental conception and execution—the issue that was so important
label: Paragraph

text: for the ideologues of the Werkbund. What defined the useful object
label: Paragraph

text: was not its mode of manufacture but its purpose. Perfection of execu-
label: Paragraph

text: tion should be the aim of hand-work and machine-work alike. In both
label: Paragraph

text: cases the maker should not express individuality but should be the
label: Paragraph

text: transmitter of impersonal cultural values. Loos’s enthusiasm for the
label: Paragraph

text: English Arts and Crafts movement was based not only on the quality
label: Paragraph

text: ofits workmanship, but also on the fact that it did not strive for the wil-
label: Paragraph

text: fully new, but respected tradition and custom.
label: Paragraph

text: It was as a writer of polemical articles that Loos first became
label: Paragraph

text: known. His aphoristic, witty, and sarcastic pieces, which gained him as
label: Paragraph

text: many enemies as friends, resembled the writings of his close friend, the
label: Paragraph

text: poet Karl Kraus (1874-1936), editor and sole writer of the satirical
label: Paragraph

text: journal Die Fackel (The Torch), published from 1899 to 1936. In this
label: Paragraph

text: journal Kraus pursued a relentless campaign against the Austrian cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural and political establishment and its journalists, whose abuse of
label: Paragraph

text: language he saw as betraying unfathomable depths of hypocrisy and
label: Paragraph

text: moral degradation.’ Loos himself started a journal—Das Andere (The
label: Paragraph

text: Other)—which, however, appeared in only two numbers in 1903, as
label: Paragraph

text: supplements in Peter Altenberg’s journal Die Kunst. This publication,
label: Paragraph

text: subtitled 4 Journal for the Introduction of Western Civilization into
label: Caption

text: Austria, paralleled Die Fackel’s cultural critique in the sphere of the
label: Paragraph

text: useful arts, comparing Austrian culture unfavourably with that of
label: Paragraph

text: England and America. Loos’s articles attacked not only Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: middle-class culture, but also the very ‘avant-garde’ culture that aimed
label: Paragraph

text: to supersede it.?
label: Paragraph

text: Loos’s writings shifted the debate on the reform of the applied arts
label: Paragraph

text: into a new register—one that was eventually to turn him into the
label: Paragraph

text: unwitting father figure of the 1920s Modern Movement. In his essay
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Ornament and Crime’ (1908), he claimed that the elimination of
label: Paragraph

text: ornament from useful objects was the result of a cultural evolution
label: Paragraph

text: leading to the abolition of waste and superfluity from human labour.
label: Paragraph

text: This process was not harmful but beneficial to culture, reducing the
label: Paragraph

text: time spent on manual labour and releasing energy for the life of the
label: Paragraph

text: mind.
label: Paragraph

text: The essay was not merely an attack on the Viennese Secession and
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil, it was also an attack on the Werkbund, founded a year
label: Paragraph

text: earlier. As we have seen, Muthesius’s aim for the Werkbund was to give
label: Paragraph

text: the artist a form-giving role within industry, and thus to establish the
label: Paragraph

text: Gestalt of the machine age. ’To Loos, this was unacceptable—not, as for
label: Paragraph

text: Van de Velde and Gropius, because it would destroy the freedom of the
label: Paragraph

text: artist but precisely because it envisaged the artist as the primary agent
label: Paragraph

text: in the creation of everyday objects. Loos believed that the ‘style of an
label: Paragraph

text: epoch’ was always the result of multiple economic and cultural forces.
label: Paragraph

text: It was not something which the producer, aided by the artist, should
label: Paragraph

text: try to impose on the consumer: ‘Germany makes, the world takes. At
label: Paragraph

text: least it should. But it does not want to. It wants to create its own forms
label: Paragraph

text: for its own life rather than have them imposed by some arbitrary pro-
label: Paragraph

text: ducers’ association.”
label: Paragraph

text: With his aim of involving the artist in industry, Muthesius (Loos’s
label: Paragraph

text: argument implied} was merely substituting form for ornament in an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to add a fictitious ‘spiritual’ quality to the social economy and
label: Paragraph

text: to bind Kultur and Zivilisation together in a new organic synthesis. But
label: Paragraph

text: such a synthesis was neither possible nor necessary. An ineradicable
label: Paragraph

text: gap had opened up between art-value and use-value. In tearing them
label: Paragraph

text: apart, capitalism had liberated them both. Art and the design of use-
label: Paragraph

text: objects now existed as independent and autonomous practices: “We are
label: Paragraph

text: grateful to [the nineteenth century] for the magnificent accomplish-
label: Paragraph

text: ment of having separated the arts and the crafts once and for all.’* The
label: Paragraph

text: search for the ‘style of the time’ that Muthesius’s types were intended
label: Paragraph

text: to express was still based on a nostalgia for the pre-industrial ‘organic’
label: Paragraph

text: society. In fact, a style of the modern age already existed—in industrial
label: Paragraph

text: products without any artistic pretensions:
label: Paragraph

text: All those trades which have managed to keep this superfluous creature [the
label: Paragraph

text: artist] out of their workshops are at present at the peak of their ability. . .
label: Paragraph

text: [their] products . . . capture the style of our time so well that we do not even
label: Paragraph

text: look on them as having style. They have become entwined with our thoughts
label: Paragraph

text: and feelings. Our carriage construction, our glasses, our optical instruments,
label: Paragraph

text: our umbrellas and canes, our luggage and saddlery, our silver cigarette cases,
label: Paragraph

text: our jewellery... and clothes—they are all modern.*
label: Paragraph

text: The attempt consciously to create the formal ‘types’ of the new age was
label: Paragraph

text: doomed to fail, just as Van de Velde’s attempt to create a new ornament
label: Paragraph

text: had failed: “No one has tried to put his podgy finger into the turning
label: Paragraph

text: wheel of time without having his hand torn off.”
label: Paragraph

text: According to Loos, art could now survive in only two (absolutely
label: Paragraph

text: antithetical) forms: firstly as the free creation of works of art that no
label: Paragraph

text: longer had any social responsibility and were therefore able to project
label: Paragraph

text: ideas into the future and criticize contemporary society; and secondly
label: Paragraph

text: in the design of buildings which embodied the collective memory.
label: Paragraph

text: Loos schematized these buildings as Denkmal (the monument) and
label: Paragraph

text: Grabmal (the tomb).’ For Loos, the private house belonged to the cat-
label: Paragraph

text: egory of the useful, not to that of the monument, hence the rarity in his
label: Paragraph

text: houses of a fully developed classical language, except for a brief period
label: Paragraph

text: between rgrg and 1923 (see page 83).
label: Paragraph

text: Decorum
label: Title

text: Loos identified the surviving realm of the monument with the antique:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘The architect’, he said, ‘is a stonemason who has learned Latin,®
label: Paragraph

text: echoing Vitruvius’s statement that knowledge of building grows
label: Paragraph

text: equally out of fabrica (material) and rafio (reason).’ His attitude to the
label: Paragraph

text: classical tradition differed from that of Otto Wagner or Behrens, for
label: Paragraph

text: whom a synthesis between art (spirit, soul) and rationality was still
label: Paragraph

text: possible, and who wanted to adapt classicism to modern conditions.
label: Paragraph

text: For Loos, as for Kraus, the antique had preserved in language the

text: The critical reception of Loos
label: Title

text: Until the 1970s, architectural historians tended to cast Loos as a proto-
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist and to attribute the apparent contradictions in his writings
label: Paragraph

text: and work to his position as a ‘transitory’ historical figure. The chief
label: Paragraph

text: problem for these critics lay in what seemed to be Loos’s ambivalence
label: Paragraph

text: towards conflicting values of tradition and modernity. On the one
label: Paragraph

text: hand, his harsh rejection of ornament and the applied arts and his
label: Paragraph

text: belief in the implacable forces of history suggested that he had settled
label: Paragraph

text: for a new technical culture, devoid of the ‘aura’ of the pre-industrial
label: Paragraph

text: world but still somehow heir to an anonymous craft tradition. On the
label: Paragraph

text: other hand he appeared as the defender of this tradition against the
label: Paragraph

text: encroachments of Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: However, certain critics of the 1970s argued that beneath the ‘con-
label: Paragraph

text: tradictions’ of Loos’s thought lay a more profound consistency and the
label: Paragraph

text: possibility of an architecture (and by extension a culture) in which
label: Paragraph

text: tradition would continue to coexist in unresolved tension with a domi-
label: Paragraph

text: nant technology.”’
label: Paragraph

text: Itis undeniable that in Loos’s architecture there is a resistance to the
label: Paragraph

text: Hegelian idea of history as a process of overcoming (Aufbebung) and a
label: Paragraph

text: tendency to create montages of different ‘languages’. Yet, Loos’s
label: Paragraph

text: most persistent idea—that the forms of use-objects, including those of
label: Paragraph

text: non-monumental architecture, should owe nothing to artistic inten-
label: Paragraph

text: tion—seems to contradict his own practice. The removal of ornament
label: Paragraph

text: from the facades of his houses was a deliberate ‘artistic’ gesture.
label: Paragraph

text: Certainly it was taken as such by the next generation of architects, who
label: Paragraph

text: sought by this means to create precisely the resolution between tech-
label: Paragraph

text: nology and art that Loos said was impossible. For Loos the unadorned
label: Paragraph

text: facade concealed individuality, for Le Corbusier it revealed Platonic
label: Paragraph

text: beauty.

text: Expressionism and
label: Title

text: Futurism
label: Title

text: Around 1910, the visual arts reached a new level of abstraction, going
label: Paragraph

text: further in the rejection of the concept of art as imitation than ever
label: Paragraph

text: before. These new developments originated in French Post-impres-
label: Paragraph

text: sionist and Fauve painting and quickly spread to other European
label: Paragraph

text: countries, taking the form of Expressionism in Germany and Futurism
label: Paragraph

text: in Italy. In France, progressive art movements and conservative art
label: Paragraph

text: institutions were to a large extent capable of coexistence, but when the
label: Paragraph

text: new formal experiments spread to Germany and Italy, they became
label: Paragraph

text: associated with movements that were diametrically opposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: academic establishment. As a result the architectural avant-gardes
label: Paragraph

text: were increasingly assimilated into the sphere of the visual arts and
label: Paragraph

text: detached from a specifically tectonic tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Both German Expressionism and Italian Futurism started as move-
label: Paragraph

text: ments in the visual arts and literature, though they soon attracted
label: Paragraph

text: architects dissatisfied both with a moribund Jugendstil and its neo-
label: Paragraph

text: classical alternative. The Expressionists and Futurists were in close
label: Paragraph

text: touch with each other: the Futurists’ various manifestos were pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished in the Expressionist magazine Der Sturm and in 1912 the
label: Paragraph

text: Futurists exhibited their work in Der Sturm gallery. But although their
label: Paragraph

text: artistic roots were the same, the two movements differed in at least one
label: Paragraph

text: crucial respect: while the Expressionists were torn between a Utopian
label: Paragraph

text: view of modern technology and a Romantic nostalgia for the Vo/, the
label: Paragraph

text: Futurists totally rejected tradition, seeing in technology the basis for a
label: Paragraph

text: new culture of the masses.
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist architecture
label: Title

text: Expressionist architecture is notoriously difficult to define. As Iain
label: Paragraph

text: Boyd Whyte has observed, the movement has usually been defined in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of what it is not (rationalism, functionalism, and so on) rather
label: Paragraph

text: than what it is,* and there is some truth in the opinion that
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism is a permanent and recurrent tendency in modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Buildings which are commonly classified as Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: include such divergent groups as the early work of Hans Poelzig, the
label: Paragraph

text: Jugendstil ‘Amsterdam School’, and architects of the 1920s such as
label: Paragraph

text: Erich Mendelsohn and Hugo Hiring; but these are also often more
label: Paragraph

text: fruitfully discussed in other contexts. Here, we will concentrate on
label: Paragraph

text: what is generally recognized as the crowning period of Expressionism
label: Paragraph

text: as a multi-genre and politically involved movement between rg14 and
label: Paragraph

text: tgat. The focus will be on the group that formed round the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Bruno Taut (1880-1930) during this period, the most important
label: Paragraph

text: members of which—beside Taut himself—were Walter Gropius and
label: Paragraph

text: the critic and art historian Adolf Behne (1885-1948).
label: Paragraph

text: Although Adolf Behne was the first to use the term ‘Expressionist’
label: Paragraph

text: in connection with architecture (in an article in Der Sturm of tg15), it is

label: Paragraph

text: moment.

text: Expressionism and politics
label: Title

text: Taut’s city crown was an attempt to give artistic form to Pyotr
label: Paragraph

text: Kropotkin’s anarchism."4 Based on the idea of dispersed Garden Cities
label: Caption

text: as the alternatives to the modern metropolis, it represented an anti-
label: Paragraph

text: urban ideology which—for all their ideological differences—was
label: Paragraph

text: shared by the radical conservatives. But, despite his antagonism to
label: Paragraph

text: many aspects of Marxism, Taut supported workers’ councils and, like
label: Paragraph

text: many other Expressionists, became involved with the revolution that
label: Paragraph

text: swept Germany in 1918. With Gropius and Behne, he founded the
label: Paragraph

text: Arbeitsrat fur Kunst (AFK). This was a trade union of artists modelled
label: Paragraph

text: on the workers’ soviets that were a feature of the revolution, and more
label: Paragraph

text: particularly on the Proletarian Council of Intellectual Workers, an
label: Paragraph

text: outgrowth of Kurt Hiller’s Activist literary movement. Taking his cue
label: Paragraph

text: from the political ambitions of that movement, Taut envisaged a group
label: Paragraph

text: of architects within the AFK who would take control of every aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: the visual environment. In an open letter of November 1918 addressed
label: Paragraph

text: ‘To the Socialist Government’, he wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: Art and life must form a unity. Art should no longer be the delight of the few,
label: Paragraph

text: but the good fortune of the life of the masses. The aim is the fusion of the arts
label: Paragraph

text: under the wing of a great architecture ... From now on, the artist alone will be
label: Paragraph

text: the modeller of the sensibilities of the ¥4/&, responsible for the visible fabric of
label: Paragraph

text: the new state. [le must determine the form-giving process from the statue
label: Paragraph

text: Dada and Expressionism
label: Title

text: Some of the pictorial fantasies exhibited in the Exhibition for Unknown
label: Paragraph

text: Architects were by artists associated with the Berlin Dada movement—
label: Paragraph

text: for example Jefim Golyscheff and Raoul Hausmann. The work of this
label: Paragraph

text: group stands somewhat apart from that of the main group of Expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sionists, not only in terms of artistic technique but also in terms of
label: Paragraph

text: ideology. The Berlin Dada movement had emerged from Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: cabaret, but its rhetoric was often activist in tone and it rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist belief that ethical and cultural change could be effected by
label: Paragraph

text: a ‘spiritual’ revolution. ‘It is a false notion’, wrote Dadaist Richard
label: Paragraph

text: Hiilsenbeck in 1917, ‘that an improvement in the world can be achieved
label: Paragraph

text: via the power of intellectuals’."* Two years later Hausmann, Hiilsen-
label: Paragraph

text: beck, and Golyscheff wrote a satirical manifesto calling for a ‘battle
label: Paragraph

text: most brutal against all schools of so-called Geistige Arbeiter [spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: worker] . . . against their concealed middle-classness and against
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism and neoclassical culture as represented by Der Sturm’.
label: Paragraph

text: The Dadaists belonged to the extreme Left and had supported the
label: Paragraph

text: Communist Spartacus League which led a workers’ uprising in
label: Paragraph

text: January 191g. In contrast to the earnestness of the AFK, they used the
label: Paragraph

text: weapons of mockery and ridicule to discredit the Expressionist move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, which in their opinion had betrayed the revolution of 1918 by
label: Paragraph

text: siding with the Social Democrats rather than the Communists. In the
label: Paragraph

text: style of their rhetoric and in some of their formal techniques, though
label: Paragraph

text: not in their ideology, the Dadaists owed a great debt to Marinetti and
label: Paragraph

text: the Futurists. It is to this movement that we will now turn.

text: Futurism
label: Title

text: The last quarter of the nineteenth century had seen an unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: development of new technologies, including electric light, the tele-
label: Paragraph

text: phone, and the automobile. Futurism was the first artistic movement
label: Paragraph

text: to see these developments as necessarily implying a total revolution in
label: Paragraph

text: everyday culture. Whereas previous avant-gardes, from Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: to Expressionism, had sought to rescue tradition by means of the very
label: Paragraph

text: modernity that threatened to destroy it, Futurism advocated the oblit-
label: Paragraph

text: eration of all traces of traditional culture and the creation of a totally
label: Paragraph

text: new, machine-based culture of the masses.
label: Paragraph

text: The movement, based in Milan, was ‘founded’ when the writer

text: newspaper Le Figaro in 1909. The manifesto was a hymn of praise to
label: Paragraph

text: the total mechanization of life. Marinetti’s ideas were strongly influ-
label: Paragraph

text: enced not only by Henri Bergson, with his concept of reality as process,
label: Paragraph

text: but also by Georges Sorel who, in his book Reflections on Violence
label: Paragraph

text: (1908), had promoted the idea of a spontaneous activism based on
label: Paragraph

text: myth, arguing that violence was a necessary and purifying force in the
label: Paragraph

text: political life of the proletariat. Combining two apparently contradic-
label: Paragraph

text: tory ideas, anarchism and nationalism, Marinetti believed that the
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous vitality of the masses had to be harnessed by an elite to the
label: Paragraph

text: interests of the state. As he was to write in the 1920s: ‘We should aspire
label: Paragraph

text: to the creation of a type of man who is not human, from whom will
label: Paragraph

text: have been eliminated moral pain, goodness, and love, the passions that
label: Paragraph

text: alone can corrode inexhaustible vital energy.” Marinetti deliberately
label: Paragraph

text: aimed at a mass audience. In attacking humanist values he made use of
label: Paragraph

text: a wide range of rhetorical devices, including burlesque, parody, and
label: Paragraph

text: hyperbole, as well as of sheer buffoonery. In his use of new grammatical
label: Paragraph

text: and typographical forms he transformed the medium of the manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: into a literary genre in its own right—one that was to exert a strong
label: Paragraph

text: influence on Dada and the Russian avant-garde.”
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1909 and 1914 Marinetti and a small group of writers,
label: Paragraph

text: painters, and musicians published about 50 manifestos on every con-
label: Paragraph

text: ceivable aspect of cultural life, deliberately mixing high and low art
label: Paragraph

text: forms. These manifestos contained ideas that have remained impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant sources for all subsequent avant-gardes and neo-avant-gardes.
label: Paragraph

text: The chief theoretical statement of the movement was ‘The Technical
label: Paragraph

text: Manifesto of Futurist Painting’,?? published in April rgro and signed
label: Paragraph

text: by the painters Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916), Carlo Carra, Luigi
label: Caption

text: Russolo, Giacomo Balla, and Gino Severini. The manifesto sought to
label: Paragraph

text: adapt the mimetic practices of art to epistemological changes implied
label: Paragraph

text: by nineteenth-century mathematics and physics, especially in the rep-
label: Paragraph

text: resentation of change and movement. The theory that it presented was
label: Paragraph

text: a kind of subjective realism, strongly influenced, as was Expressionism,
label: Paragraph

text: by late-nineteenth-century German aesthetic philosophy, much of
label: Paragraph

text: which had been translated into Italian, as well as by non-Euclidean
label: Paragraph

text: geometry and Einsteinian physics. The painting, it was argued, should
label: Paragraph

text: no longer be conceived as the imitation of an external scene but as the
label: Paragraph

text: registration of the mental states caused by the scene. Both painter and
label: Paragraph

text: object were seen to occupy a unified spatio-temporal field: “The gesture
label: Paragraph

text: that we would reproduce will no longer be a fixed moment in a univer-
label: Paragraph

text: sal dynamism, it will be the dynamism itself.” Later, Boccioni gave
label: Paragraph

text: this idea more precision:
label: Paragraph

text: This synthesis—given the tendency to render the concrete in terms of the
label: Paragraph

text: abstract—can be expressed only . . . by precisely dimensioned geometrical
label: Paragraph

text: forms, instead of by traditional methods (now devalued by the mechanical
label: Paragraph

text: media) . . . If we thus make use of mathematical objects, it is the relation
label: Paragraph

text: between them that will provide the rhythm and the emotion.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Futurists became aware of Cubism in ror and quickly assimilated
label: Paragraph

text: its techniques. Boccioni’s susceptibility to Cubism and collage is
label: Paragraph

text: shown in his description of his own subsequent practice: “The disloca-
label: Paragraph

text: tion and dismemberment of objects . . . freed from accepted logic and
label: Paragraph

text: independent from each other.”’ Yet the contradiction between
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism’s demand for the autonomy of art and the Futurists’ desire to
label: Paragraph

text: fuse art and life was never fully resolved. This was to remain one of the
label: Paragraph

text: main doctrinal conflicts in the history of Modernism, as we shall see
label: Paragraph

text: when we consider the development of Modernist architecture after the
label: Paragraph

text: First World War.
label: Paragraph

text: Futurism and architecture
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: first was by 20-year-old Enrico Prampolini, who belonged to the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman branch of the movement, and the second was by Boccioni
label: Paragraph

text: (although it was not published until 1960). Boccioni’s manifesto bears a

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Antonio Sant’Elia
label: Title

text: The probable reason that Boccioni’s architectural manifesto remained
label: Paragraph

text: unpublished despite its obvious importance was that in July 1914
label: Paragraph

text: another such manifesto was written by Antonio Sant’Elia (1888-1916).
label: Paragraph

text: This architect’s accession to the Futurist movement coincided with an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of the work of a rival group of artists, the Nuove Tendenze,
label: Paragraph

text: in which Sant’Elia showed an extraordinary series of perspective
label: Paragraph

text: drawings representing his idea of the architecture of the future. The
label: Paragraph

text: relationship between these drawings and the Futurist movement has
label: Paragraph

text: long been the subject of controversy.
label: Paragraph

text: The ideas expressed in Sant’Elia’s ‘Manifesto of Futurist Archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture? and in the slightly shorter version of it published in the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition catalogue (the ‘Messaggio™), correspond closely with the
label: Paragraph

text: ideology of the movement, but the drawings themselves seem to con-
label: Paragraph

text: tradict it in important ways. It is likely that Sant’Elia had been in
label: Paragraph

text: contact with the Futurists for some time, and that behind the mani-
label: Paragraph

text: festo and the ‘Messaggio’ there existed an urtext written in part by
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti or Boccioni or both, so as to provide the appropriate stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: (if not intellectual) credentials. This may explain the reason for the dis-
label: Paragraph

text: crepancies between the drawings and the text, but the discrepancies
label: Paragraph

text: themselves need further elucidation.”
label: Paragraph

text: Except for three very small structures, Sant’Elia’s legacy consists
label: Paragraph

text: exclusively of architectural drawings. These are either for actual but
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt projects, mostly facade studies, or perspectives of an imagi-
label: Paragraph

text: nary architecture. The facades are in a highly ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: Liberty-Secessionist style and Sant’Elia continued to produce such
label: Paragraph

text: work until his death. The perspectives are of three kinds. The first are
label: Paragraph

text: totally unornamented, astylar compositions with generic titles such as
label: Paragraph

text: “Modern building’, ‘Monument’, and ‘Industrial building’, dated 1913
label: Caption

text: [66]. Almost certainly these drawings were influenced by the pho-
label: Paragraph

text: tographs of North American grain silos illustrated by Gropius in the
label: Caption

text: Jahrbuch des Deutschen Werkbundes of 1913, and quite possibly by the
label: Paragraph

text: stage designs of Gordon Craig and Adolfe Appia.*3 The second kind is
label: Paragraph

text: a set of drawings in which similarly abstract forms are adapted to one
label: Paragraph

text: particular industrial building type: the hydroelectric power station—a
label: Paragraph

text: type of building almost synonymous with the rapid industrialization
label: Paragraph

text: of the Po Valley in the first years of the twentieth century [53 (see
label: Caption

text: page 86) and 67].
label: Paragraph

text: Finally there is a set of drawings entitled La Citta Nuova (The New
label: Paragraph

text: City). These are very detailed and their technique is harsher and less
label: Paragraph

text: atmospheric [68]. Stepped-back floors of multi-storey apartment
label: Caption

text: blocks (resembling the powerful sloping walls of the hydroelectric
label: Paragraph

text: dams) are contrasted with vertical elevator towers, to which they are
label: Paragraph

text: connected by bridges. The ground is completely eroded with a multi-
label: Paragraph

text: level network of transport viaducts. The drawings depict a city from
label: Paragraph

text: which all traces of nature have been removed, a city dominated by a
label: Paragraph

text: plethora of horizontal and vertical distribution systems, against which
label: Paragraph

text: the facades of the apartment units seem to play a passive and secondary
label: Paragraph

text: role. Sant’Elia took elements of his city from various sources, includ-
label: Paragraph

text: ing popular illustrations of the New York City of the future, Henri
label: Paragraph

text: Sauvage’s Maison 4 Gradins in Paris (1912), and above all Otto
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner's drawings of his new transport infrastructure for Vienna

text: But, impressive as Sant’Elia’s drawings are in their dramatic repre-

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: abound in them.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, Sant’Elia’s drawings are also derived from the work of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In trying to place Expressionism and Futurism in a historical perspec-
label: Paragraph

text: tive, a salient fact emerges: both movements, whatever their other
label: Paragraph

text: differences, rejected the Enlightenment tradition of reason and
label: Paragraph

text: stressed the importance of myth and instinct in the social life of
label: Paragraph

text: nations. They denounced a rationalistic civilization which they
label: Paragraph

text: believed had sown discord in a previously unified and organic society.
label: Paragraph

text: They espoused a set of ideas—anti-materialist, anti-liberal-democra-
label: Paragraph

text: tic and anti-Marxist—which became increasingly influential in the
label: Paragraph

text: countries of western Europe in the years leading up to the First World
label: Title

text: War and which, in their extreme form, found political expression in the
label: Paragraph

text: Fascism and National Socialism of the inter-war years.

text: ‘The Avant-gardes
label: Title

text: in Holland and
label: Title

text: Russia
label: Title

text: As in the case of Expressionism and Futurism, the architectural avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardes in Holland and Russia were at first dominated by painting and
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture. In both countries formal experiments that were possible in
label: Paragraph

text: theoretical or small-scale projects met with considerable resistance
label: Paragraph

text: when applied to the constructional and programmatic needs of build-
label: Paragraph

text: ings. After the First World War, as soon as the economic and political
label: Paragraph

text: situation allowed building to resume, architectural projects in both
label: Paragraph

text: countries began to take on the characteristics of a more sober, interna-
label: Paragraph

text: tional architecture and to lose national traits which had originated
label: Paragraph

text: largely from interpretations of Cubism, Expressionism, and Futurism.
label: Paragraph

text: This chapter will describe these national movements—De Stijl in
label: Paragraph

text: Holland; Suprematism, Rationalism, and Constructivism in Russia—
label: Paragraph

text: and their transition to a Europe-wide ‘Modern Movement’ (also
label: Paragraph

text: known as ‘Neue Sachlichkeit’, ‘Functionalism’, ‘Rationalism’, or
label: Paragraph

text: ‘Neues Bauen’).
label: Paragraph

text: In both the Dutch and the Russian avant-gardes, the logic of the
label: Paragraph

text: machine became the model for art and architecture; the mind was con-
label: Paragraph

text: sidered to be able to create form independently of traditional craft,
label: Paragraph

text: implying a new alliance between painting, architecture, and mathe-
label: Paragraph

text: matical reason. Art and architecture were seen as impersonal and
label: Paragraph

text: objective and not based on individual ‘taste’.
label: Paragraph

text: The avant-garde in Holland
label: Title

text: Two opposed movements in architecture and the decorative arts flour-
label: Paragraph

text: ished in Holland during and immediately after the First World
label: Paragraph

text: War—the Amsterdam School and De Stijl. Both these movements
label: Paragraph

text: were related to Art Nouveau and the Arts and Crafts movement as well
label: Paragraph

text: as to German Expressionism; both believed in a unified style reflecting
label: Paragraph

text: the spirit of the age; both inherited the Morrisian idea that society
label: Paragraph

text: could be transformed by art; and both rejected the eclectic use of past
label: Paragraph

text: styles, striving for a new, uncoded architecture. But each inherited a
label: Paragraph

text: different strand of the earlier movements—the vitalistic, individualis-
label: Paragraph

text: tic strand in the case of the Amsterdam School and the rationalist,
label: Paragraph

text: impersonal strand in the case of De Stijl. Each movement condemned
label: Paragraph

text: the other, ignoring their shared aims and origins.’
label: Paragraph

text: The work of the Amsterdam School—whose chief exponent was
label: Paragraph

text: Michel de Klerk (1884-1923)—was characterized by the use of traditional
label: Paragraph

text: materials, in particular brick, and the free, fantastical but craftsman-like
label: Paragraph

text: working of these materials. The forms of traditional architecture were
label: Paragraph

text: not so much abandoned as transformed and made strange. Much of
label: Paragraph

text: the most important work of the Amsterdam School was built between
label: Paragraph

text: 1914 and 1923 and is to be found in the many public housing projects
label: Paragraph

text: that were part of the vast urban renewal programme being undertaken
label: Paragraph

text: in Amsterdam at the time under the direction of Berlage.
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl
label: Title

text: The De Stijl movement, though its origins lay, like those of the
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam School, in the decorative arts, developed an ornamenta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion that reflected the influence of Cubism and rejected craftsmanship
label: Paragraph

text: in favour of a geometrical anti-naturalism. In 1917 the painter Theo van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg (1883-1931) published the first issue of De S7ij/, a magazine
label: Paragraph

text: promoting modern art. The term ‘De Stil’ is normally applied to both
label: Paragraph

text: the magazine and the movement to which it gave its name. The origi-
label: Paragraph

text: nal group included the painters Piet Mondrian (1872-1944), van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg, Vilmos Huszar (1884-1960}, and Bart van der Leck
label: Paragraph

text: (1876-1958), the sculptor Georges Vantongerloo (1886-1965), and the
label: Paragraph

text: architects Jan Wils (1891-1927), Robert van’t Hoff (1887-1979), Gerrit
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld (1888-1964), and J. J. P. Oud (1890-1963). The group’s identity,
label: Paragraph

text: however, had less to do with its specific membership, which was highly
label: Paragraph

text: volatile, than with its doctrine as defined in the first De Stijl Manifesto
label: Paragraph

text: of 1918 and in later issues of the magazine. De Stij/ was edited and dom-
label: Paragraph

text: inated by van Doesburg and became an important organ of the
label: Paragraph

text: international avant-garde until it ceased publication in 1932.
label: Paragraph

text: Theory
label: Title

text: The theoretical apparatus of De Stijl was a variant of existing (mostly
label: Paragraph

text: Symbolist and Futurist-derived) doctrine, and the movement saw
label: Paragraph

text: itself as a crusade in the common cause of Modernism. It maintained
label: Paragraph

text: close ties with avant-garde movements in the different arts abroad,
label: Paragraph

text: including Dada (van Doesburg himself, under the pseudonym Aldo
label: Paragraph

text: Camini, published Dada poetry in De Stj/).
label: Paragraph

text: The three main postulates of the movement can be roughly sum-
label: Paragraph

text: marized as follows: each art form must realize its own nature based on
label: Paragraph

text: its materials and codes—only then can the generative principles
label: Paragraph

text: governing all the visual arts (indeed, all art) be revealed; as the spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: awareness of society increases, so will art fulfil its historical (Hegelian)
label: Paragraph

text: destiny and become reabsorbed into daily life; art is not opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: science and technology—both art and science are concerned with the
label: Paragraph

text: discovery and demonstration of the underlying laws of nature and not
label: Title

text: with nature’s superficial and transient appearance (the theory,
label: Paragraph

text: however, did not take into account the possibility art could still be a
label: Paragraph

text: form of imitation).
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl belonged to the millennialist tradition of Expressionism
label: Paragraph

text: and Futurism. Although it lacked any obvious political dimension, it
label: Paragraph

text: was nonetheless Utopian; it imagined a future in which social divisions
label: Paragraph

text: would be dissolved and power dispersed. It combined a commitment
label: Paragraph

text: to modernity with an idealism that associated scientific and technical
label: Paragraph

text: change with spiritual as well as material progress. The metaphysics of
label: Paragraph

text: the movement were to a large extent taken from the Theosophist and
label: Paragraph

text: Neoplatonist M. J. H. Schoenmaeker, whose book The Principles of
label: Paragraph

text: Plastic Mathematics (1916) claimed that plastic mathematics was a ‘pos-
label: Paragraph

text: itive mysticism’ in which ‘we translate reality into constructions
label: Paragraph

text: controlled by our reason, later to recover these constructions in nature,
label: Paragraph

text: thus penetrating matter with plastic vision’. Schoenmaeker believed
label: Paragraph

text: that the new plastic expression (‘Neoplasticism’), born of light and
label: Paragraph

text: sound, would create a heaven on earth.”
label: Paragraph

text: The two main theorists of the movement were Mondrian and van
label: Paragraph

text: Doesburg, but they by no means agreed on all points of doctrine.
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian’s concept of Neoplasticism, based partly on Schoenmaeker
label: Paragraph

text: and partly on Kandinsky’s influential book User das Geistige in der
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst (Concerning the Spiritual in Art) of 1911, was restricted to paint-
label: Paragraph

text: ing, whereas van Doesburg attempted to apply it to architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: well. Although both Huszar and Van der Leck made important contri-
label: Paragraph

text: butions to the early development of Neoplasticism, it was Mondrian
label: Paragraph

text: who worked out its logical implications. The system that he eventually
label: Paragraph

text: arrived at was based on a radical process of reduction in which the
label: Paragraph

text: complex, accidental appearance of nature was refined to the variations
label: Paragraph

text: of an irregular orthogonal grid, partly filled in with rectangles of
label: Paragraph

text: primary colour [72]. According to Yve-Alain Bois, Mondrian org-
label: Paragraph

text: anizes the picture surface in such a way that the traditional hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: between figural objects and an illusionistic ground is abolished. In
label: Paragraph

text: Mondrian, ‘no element is more important than any other, and none
label: Paragraph

text: must escape integration’.* These structural principles of non-redun-
label: Paragraph

text: dancy and non-hierarchy are similar to those underlying Schoenberg’s
label: Paragraph

text: atonal and serial music.* In traditional painting it is the figural object
label: Paragraph

text: that conveys the symbolic or lyrical content (as does melody in music);*
label: Paragraph

text: in Mondrian’s paintings the meaning is transposed from the repre-
label: Paragraph

text: The Russian avant-garde
label: Title

text: The reform movement in the arts followed much the same trajectory in
label: Paragraph

text: Russia as in Western Europe. A revival of the vernacular arts and crafts
label: Paragraph

text: inspired, as elsewhere, by William Morris, was initiated at two centres:
label: Paragraph

text: the estate of the railway magnate Savva Mamontov near Moscow (in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1870s) and the estate of Princess Tenisheva at Smolensk (in 1890).
label: Paragraph

text: Both were closely associated with the Pan-Slav movement. But in 1906
label: Paragraph

text: this movement itself underwent a transformation with the founding of
label: Paragraph

text: the Organization for Proletarian Culture (‘Proletkult’), by Alexandr
label: Paragraph

text: Malinovsky, self-styled “Bogdanov’ (God-gifted). Bogdanov had
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned the Social Democrats for the Bolsheviks in 1903, and his
label: Paragraph

text: new organization initiated a shift from the concept of the folk to that of
label: Paragraph

text: the proletariat, and from handicraft to science and technology.
label: Paragraph

text: According to Bogdanov the progress of the proletariat towards social-
label: Paragraph

text: ism would have to take place simultaneously on the political,
label: Paragraph

text: economic, and cultural planes. These ideas were in fact closer to those
label: Paragraph

text: of Saint-Simon than those of Marx, particularly in their call for a new
label: Paragraph

text: ‘religion’ of positivism.
label: Paragraph

text: Accommon pattern in Russia and the West can be found not only in
label: Paragraph

text: the change of emphasis from handicraft to machine-work, but also in
label: Paragraph

text: the re-emergence of the fine arts as the most important site of experi-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, linked to the concept of Gesta/t. The only substantial difference
label: Paragraph

text: was that in Russia the industrial art and fine art movements occurred
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously and became locked in a destructive ideological battle,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas in the West, though they overlapped, they occurred
label: Paragraph

text: sequentially.
label: Paragraph

text: The diversity of artistic movements that characterized the pre-rev-
label: Paragraph

text: olutionary avant-gardes in Russia, especially those deriving from
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism and Futurism, persisted in the post-revolutionary period, pre-
label: Paragraph

text: senting the historian with a bewildering array of acronyms. Support for
label: Paragraph

text: the revolution came from all artistic factions, including the most con-
label: Paragraph

text: servative, each faction identifying with its aims. For those avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects who joined the revolution, the Utopian fantasies
label: Title

text: of the period before the First World War seemed about to become a
label: Paragraph

text: historical reality.” The revolution released an explosion of creative
label: Paragraph

text: energy, in which the paths opened up by the pre-war European avant-
label: Paragraph

text: gardes were redirected towards the achievement of socialism.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Tn 1925 a new professional group was formed within the Constructivist

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of Contemporary Architects (OSA). This group was opposed to both
label: Paragraph

text: the Rationalists and the First Working Group. It sought to steer the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: tion, towards an architecture grounded in scientific method and social
label: Paragraph

text: engineering. The group’s aims reflected a trend in the Russian avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde towards reintegration and synthesis. As Leon Trotsky pointed

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: there was a turn to neoclassical calm and precision as a reaction against
label: Paragraph

text: the irrationalism of Expressionism, Futurism, and Dada.
label: Paragraph

text: The group published a journal—Contemporary Architecture!’—and

text: In the field of urbanism, OSA was caught up in the controversy

text: stead Garden Suburb in Britain. The disurbanists, on the contrary,
label: Paragraph

text: called for the progressive demolition of existing cities, except for their
label: Paragraph

text: historical cores, and the dispersal of the population over the whole
label: Paragraph

text: countryside. Ginsburg’s disurbanist views are evident from his compe-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The end of the Russian avant-garde
label: Title

text: Throughout the 1920s Russian avant-garde architects struggled to
label: Paragraph

text: hold onto their freedom of action, which usually meant the freedom to
label: Paragraph

text: put forward ideas that were more radical, both socially and artistically,
label: Paragraph

text: than those of the Communist Party. But towards the end of the rg20s
label: Paragraph

text: the gap between the avant-garde and the political establishment
label: Title

text: increased. As the Stalin government became increasingly authoritarian
label: Paragraph

text: and culturally conservative, so the architects became more Utopian—
label: Paragraph

text: as the work of Leonidov demonstrates. The same was true at the level
label: Paragraph

text: of urbanism. While the architects of OSA condemned the traditional
label: Paragraph

text: city, the Communist Party saw it as a cultural heritage that was under-
label: Paragraph

text: stood by the masses and should therefore be preserved, extended, and
label: Paragraph

text: improved. The plan for Moscow of 1935 (architect: V. N. Semenov),
label: Caption

text: though based on the city’s unique medieval structure, followed the
label: Paragraph

text: general principles of such nineteenth and early-twentieth-century city
label: Paragraph

text: plans as Haussmann’s Paris, the Ringstrasse in Vienna, and Burnham’s
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago. The official view was summed up in the slogan: “The people
label: Paragraph

text: have a right to columns.’
label: Paragraph

text: With Stalin’s first Five Year Plan of 1928, the government embarked
label: Paragraph

text: on a ruthless programme of industrial development and agricultural
label: Title

text: collectivization. This programme included the construction of a
label: Paragraph

text: number of new industrial cities sited near sources of raw material. The
label: Paragraph

text: solutions that Ginsburg and Milyutin proposed for Magnitogorsk
label: Paragraph

text: were ignored in favour of conventional centralized cities. Showing
label: Paragraph

text: little faith in Russian architects with their lack of practical experience
label: Title

text: and preoccupation with long-term, Utopian ideas, the new city man-
label: Paragraph

text: agers hired foreign architects with experience in the techniques and
label: Paragraph

text: management of new settlements. These included the German archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect Ernst May and the Swiss Hannes Meyer (who moved to Russia in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 after losing hope that socialism might be established in western
label: Paragraph

text: Europe). Such architects, however, completely misjudging the true sit-
label: Paragraph

text: uation in Russia, were disappointed when they discovered that their
label: Paragraph

text: clients were more interested in their technical skills than their
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist aesthetics—which in any case could hardly be realized
label: Paragraph

text: under the primitive conditions of the Russian building industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Two events symbolize the final death of the avant-garde in Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Russia. The first was the dissolution in 1932 of all autonomous

text: pre-war avant-gardes. A ‘return to order’ was seen to be necessary. But
label: Paragraph

text: while for some this meant a return to conservative values and a rejection
label: Paragraph

text: of modernity, for others it meant embracing the imperatives of modern
label: Paragraph

text: technology. What further complicated the situation was that both cul-
label: Paragraph

text: tural pessimists like the poet Paul Valéry and technological Utopians
label: Paragraph

text: like Le Corbusier invoked the spirit of classicism and geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: In the aftermath of the war, there was little architectural activity in
label: Paragraph

text: France until 1923, and architects were largely restricted to the design of
label: Paragraph

text: private dwellings. This chapter will discuss the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: French avant-garde as it emerged from this situation, with Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier as its most creative and energetic representative.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier before the First World War
label: Title

text: Charles Eduard Jeanneret (1887-1965), later known as Ie Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: received his training in the school of arts and crafts at La Chaux-de-
label: Paragraph

text: Fonds in French Switzerland, where he learned a trade
label: Paragraph

text: engraving—before taking the Cours Supéricur with Charles L’Eplat-
label: Paragraph

text: tenier, who persuaded him to become an architect. He worked for a few
label: Paragraph

text: watch
label: Title

text: months with Auguste Perret in Paris in 1908 and from 1910 to 1911 he
label: Paragraph

text: spent several months in Germany preparing a report on German
label: Paragraph

text: applied art commissioned by [’Eplattenier.
label: Paragraph

text: While in Germany he met Theodor Fischer, Heinrich Tessenow,
label: Paragraph

text: and Bruno Paul, worked briefly in the office of Peter Behrens, and
label: Paragraph

text: attended an important Deutscher Werkbund conterence sponsored by
label: Paragraph

text: the cement industry at which most of the luminaries of the German
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde were present. He then travelled to the Balkans, Istanbul,
label: Paragraph

text: and Athens. The journal and letters that Jeanneret wrote during this
label: Paragraph

text: voyage show that he was caught between his love of the ‘feminine’ ver-
label: Paragraph

text: nacular arts of Eastern Europe and Istanbul, and his admiration for the
label: Paragraph

text: ‘masculine’ classicism of ancient Greece, which he identified with the
label: Paragraph

text: spirit of modern rationalism. The effect of the Parthenon, combined
label: Paragraph

text: with the teaching of Perret and Behrens, converted him to classicism,
label: Paragraph

text: and he renounced the medievalizing Jugendstil tradition in which he
label: Paragraph

text: had been trained.
label: Paragraph

text: In his report on German applied art, which was entitled ‘Etude sur le
label: Paragraph

text: Mouvement de l’Art Décoratif en Allemagne’ (‘Study on the Decora-
label: Paragraph

text: tive Art Movement in Germany’), Jeanneret eulogized the tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: the French decorative arts, which he saw to be threatened by German
label: Paragraph

text: commercial competition. He was full of praise for the organizational
label: Paragraph

text: skill of the Germans, but denigrated their artistic taste. Somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: inconsistently, however, he admitted his admiration for the new
label: Paragraph

text: German neoclassical movement, claiming that ‘Empire’ was the pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gressive style of the day, being at once “aristocratic, sober, and serious’.
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret’s early work already shows the desire to reconcile archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tectural tradition with modern technology that was to characterize his
label: Paragraph

text: entire career. While practising in La Chaux-de-Fonds between 1911
label: Paragraph

text: and 1917 he was engaged in three types of project: research into the
label: Paragraph

text: application of industrial techniques to mass housing within a Sitte-
label: Paragraph

text: esque Garden Suburb framework, bourgeois interiors in the Empire
label: Paragraph

text: and Directoire styles; and the design of neoclassical villas. Of the three
label: Paragraph

text: villas that he built in the vicinity of La Chaux-de-Fonds—the Villa
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret (912), the Villa Favre-Jacot (1912), and the Villa Schwob
label: Paragraph

text: (t916)—the first two were strongly influenced by Behrens’s neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: houses and the third by Perret’s use of the reinforced-concrete frame.
label: Paragraph

text: During this period, frequent visits to Paris kept him in touch with both
label: Paragraph

text: Perret and French decorative art circles, in which his ‘Etude’ had
label: Paragraph

text: enjoyed something of a succés d ‘estime.*
label: Paragraph

text: In 1917 Jeanneret moved permanently to Paris, where he was able to
label: Paragraph

text: set up an office within the business ramifications of an old friend, the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer and entrepreneur Max Dubois. He also began to paint in oils
label: Paragraph

text: under the guidance of the artist Amédée Ozenfant, whom he met in
label: Paragraph

text: 1918. Calling themselves ‘Purists’, the two immediately collaborated on
label: Paragraph

text: a book, Aprés fe Cubisme, and with the poet Paul Dermée founded the
label: Paragraph

text: magazine L'Esprit Nouveau in 1920.
label: Paragraph

text: LEsprit Nouveau
label: Title

text: The review (from which Dermée was soon ejected on account of his
label: Paragraph

text: Dada tendencies) was published between October 1920 and January
label: Paragraph

text: 1925 in 28 editions. Its original subtitle, Revue Internationale d'Esthé-
label: Paragraph

text: tique, was soon changed to Revue Internationale Ilustrée de V'Activité
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine, and the following list of subjects was announced:
label: Paragraph

text: literature, architecture, painting, sculpture, music, pure and applied
label: Title

text: science, experimental aesthetics, the aesthetic of the engineer, urban-
label: Title

text: ism, philosophy, sociology, economics, politics, modern life, theatre,
label: Paragraph

text: spectacles, and sports. Most of the articles were written by Ozenfant
label: Paragraph

text: and Jeanneret themselves under various pseudonyms.’ (At this point,
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret adopted the name of Le Corbusier, though he continued to
label: Paragraph

text: sign his paintings with his family name until 1928.)
label: Paragraph

text: The principal theme of L'Esprit Nouveau, already developed in
label: Paragraph

text: Apreés le Cubisme, was the problematic relation between art and indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial society. The review shared with De Stijl the idea that the modern
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized world implied a change from individualism to collec-
label: Paragraph

text: tivism. Both also agreed that art and science were not opposed to each
label: Paragraph

text: other, even if they used different means, and that their union would
label: Paragraph

text: result in a new aesthetic. What differentiated L'Esprit Nouveau from
label: Paragraph

text: De Stijl was the belief that this new aesthetic would be classical in
label: Paragraph

text: spirit. This idea was underlined by the constant juxtaposition of old
label: Paragraph

text: and new: monographs on such French classical ‘masters’ as Poussin and
label: Title

text: Ingres were interleaved with articles by Charles Henry on the science
label: Paragraph

text: of aesthetics;* the Parthenon was compared to a modern automobile,
label: Paragraph

text: and so on. The affinity between art and science was seen to be based on
label: Paragraph

text: their common approximation to a condition of stasis, harmony, and
label: Paragraph

text: invariability. Science and technology had reached a state of perfection
label: Paragraph

text: of which the Greeks had only dreamed. Reason could now create
label: Paragraph

text: machines of extreme precision; feeling, allied to reason, could create
label: Paragraph

text: works of art of an equally precise plastic beauty: ‘No one today denies
label: Paragraph

text: the aesthetic that emanates from the constructions of modern industry
label: Paragraph

text: ... machines display such proportions, plays of volume and materiality
label: Paragraph

text: that many are true works of art, because they embody number, which is
label: Paragraph

text: to say order.’4 There was nothing new in the identification of modern
label: Paragraph

text: technology with classicism—it had been an essential part of
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius’s post-Arts and Crafts aesthetic doctrine (see page 58). But
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism had opened the way to a more abstract, Platonic idea of classi-
label: Paragraph

text: cism, and it was in this form that the equation technology-classicism
label: Paragraph

text: reappeared in L'Esprit Nouveau.
label: Paragraph

text: The connection between science and Platonic forms depended on a
label: Paragraph

text: highly selective view of modern science. It tended to ignore such nine-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth-century developments as the life sciences and non-Euclidean
label: Paragraph

text: geometries with their counterintuitive, often destabilizing, models of
label: Paragraph

text: reality. Even more problematic was the fact that in the new world of
label: Paragraph

text: objectivity and collectivism anticipated by L'Esprit Nouveau the posi-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of the artist remained untouched. De Stijl and the Constructivists,
label: Paragraph

text: arguing from similar principles to L’Esprit Nouveau, had foreseen a
label: Paragraph

text: time when the artist would become redundant. But for L'Esprit
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau, the artist played an essential role within a modern society
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by science and technology—that of making visible the
label: Paragraph

text: unity of the age. Francoise Will-Levaillant’s judgement is difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: dispute: “The positivism applied by L’Esprit Nouveau founders on the
label: Paragraph

text: contradiction between materialism, to which it leans a priori, and ide-
label: Paragraph

text: alism, which completely overdetermines all reasoning and choice.’ An
label: Paragraph

text: unresolved dualism was, indeed, at the very core of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: system of ideas. “The first goal of architecture’, he wrote, ‘ is to create
label: Paragraph

text: organisms that are perfectly viable. The second, where modern archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture really begins, is to move our senses with harmonized forms and
label: Paragraph

text: our minds by the perception of the mathematical relationships which
label: Paragraph

text: unify them.” In such statements the connection between technical via-
label: Paragraph

text: bility and aesthetic form is merely asserted, never argued. Although
label: Paragraph

text: forms became ‘lawful’ only through technique, they were nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: somehow self-validating. This unresolved contradiction between
label: Paragraph

text: materialism and idealism was not, however, restricted to the pages of
label: Paragraph

text: L'Esprit Nouveau, to one degree or another it characterized the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement of the 1920s as a whole.
label: Paragraph

text: The objet-type
label: Title

text: t was in formulating an ideology of modern painting that Ozenfant
label: Paragraph

text: and Jeanneret developed many of the architectural ideas that later
label: Paragraph

text: appeared in L'Esprit Nouveau. In Aprés le Cubisme (1918) and in the
label: Paragraph

text: essay ‘Le Purisme” an idea that was to play an important part in Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's architectural theory was introduced: that of the objet-type.
label: Paragraph

text: In these texts, the authors praise Cubism for its abolition of narrative,
label: Paragraph

text: its simplification of forms, its compression of pictorial depth, and its
label: Paragraph

text: method of selecting certain objects as emblems of modern life. But
label: Paragraph

text: they condemn it for its ‘decorative’ deformation and fragmentation of
label: Paragraph

text: the object and demand the object’s reinstatement. ‘Of all the recent
label: Paragraph

text: schools of painting, only Cubism foresaw the advantages of choosing
label: Paragraph

text: selected objects... But by a paradoxical error, instead of sifting out the
label: Paragraph

text: general laws of these objects, Cubism showed their accidental
label: Paragraph

text: aspects.”* By virtue of these general laws, the object would become an
label: Paragraph

text: objet-type, its Platonic forms resulting from a process analogous to
label: Paragraph

text: natural selection, becoming ‘banal’, susceptible to infinite duplication,
label: Paragraph

text: the stuff of everyday life [90].°

text: Urbanism
label: Title

text: As we have seen, Le Corbusier’s earliest urban projects in Chaux-de-
label: Paragraph

text: Fonds were related to the Garden City movement. But in 1920, he
label: Paragraph

text: turned his attention to the problem of the modern metropolis, address-
label: Paragraph

text: ing issues of circulation and hygiene with which the urbanists in Paris
label: Paragraph

text: had been concerned for some time.” The first such project—the Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporaine, shown at the Salon d’Automne of 1922—was a
label: Paragraph

text: schematic proposal for a city of 3 million people on an ideal site [101].
label: Paragraph

text: The project is based on the belief that the metropolis is valuable a
label: Paragraph

text: priori. Its efficiency as a node of culture depends on its historical asso-
label: Paragraph

text: ciation with a particular location. But to be preserved it has first to be
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed. To counter the city’s increasing congestion and the conse-
label: Paragraph

text: quent flight of its inhabitants to the suburbs, it will be necessary both to
label: Paragraph

text: increase its density and to decrease the area covered by buildings. Using
label: Paragraph

text: American skyscraper technology, the project proposes widely spaced
label: Paragraph

text: office towers 200 metres high, and continuous residential superblocks
label: Paragraph

text: of 12 storcys, the rest of the space being turned into parkland traversed
label: Paragraph

text: by a rectilinear network of high-speed roads. Modern technology
label: Paragraph

text: makes it possible to combine the advantages of the Garden City with
label: Paragraph

text: those of the traditional city. Instead of the population moving to the
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs, the suburhs move into the city.
label: Paragraph
