label: Paragraph

text: a pattern of ‘setbacks’—‘a redents’. This idea had two sources: the

label: Paragraph

text: In the Ville Contemporaine and the Ville Radieuse, two absolute
label: Paragraph

text: values are juxtaposed: nature and technology. Work and domestic life
label: Paragraph

text: take place in high-rise structures; cultivation of the spirit and the body

label: Paragraph

text: chance is eliminated from urban experience. The social problems con-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: years. Despite its faults, however, the Corbusian city drew attention to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Regional Syndicalism
label: Title

text: In the late 1920s Le Corbusier became a militant member of the Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Syndicalist group led by Hubert Lagardelle (1874-1958) and Philippe
label: Paragraph

text: Lamour (1903-1992). The group was anti-liberal and anti-Marxist and
label: Paragraph

text: be
label: Title

text: ideologically aligned with contemporary Fascist movements in France
label: Paragraph

text: and Italy. Le Corbusier became an editor and major contributor to the
label: Paragraph

text: group’s journal Plans and its successor Prélude. Influenced by Pierre-
label: Paragraph

text: Joseph Proudhon and Georges Sorel, the group called for the abolition
label: Paragraph

text: of parliamentary democracy, and for the creation of a government of
label: Paragraph

text: technical elites, on the Saint-Simonian principle of the ‘administration
label: Paragraph

text: of things, not the government of people’, dedicated to a planned
label: Paragraph

text: economy. It believed that the alienation of modern social life could be
label: Paragraph

text: alleviated not by socialism, with its concept of abstract man, but by a
label: Paragraph

text: return to /’homme réel and to the spirit of community characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: pre-industrial societies. This anti-Enlightenment, anti-materialist
label: Paragraph

text: position was the equivalent of the Vo/kisch movement in Germany, and
label: Paragraph

text: had the same tolerance for a technological Modernism on condition
label: Paragraph

text: that it was not dominated by finance capital.”
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's new journalistic activities coincided with a revival of
label: Paragraph

text: his earlier interest in vernacular architecture—an interest which had
label: Paragraph

text: been submerged but never destroyed by his concern for new systems of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural production. In his book Une Maison, un Palais he wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: lyrical if somewhat patronizing terms of the fishermen’s cottages at Le
label: Paragraph

text: Piquey near La Rochelle where he spent his summer vacations

label: Paragraph

text: If we compare Le Corbusier’s Neo-Syndicalist ideas with those he
label: Paragraph

text: had expressed in L'Esprit Nouveau 15 years earlier, we find a consider-
label: Paragraph

text: able shift of emphasis. The main problem for L'Esprit Nowveau was the
label: Paragraph

text: conflict between eternal cultural values and modern technology, which
label: Paragraph

text: it tried to resolve by conflating technology with Platonic ‘invariables’.
label: Paragraph

text: In the late 1920s Le Corbusier modified this static model, acknowledg-
label: Paragraph

text: ing the existence of uncertainty and change. Elements that had been
label: Paragraph

text: recessive in the L'Esprit Nouveau philosophy—disorder, organic forms,
label: Paragraph

text: immediate experience, intuition—come to the forefront. If geometry
label: Paragraph

text: and balance are still seen as the ultimate measures of value, they are
label: Paragraph

text: now thought to be as much the result of instinct as of an abstract ratio-
label: Paragraph

text: nality. The task of modern architecture is seen as the fusion of universal
label: Paragraph

text: technology with age-old wisdom:
label: Title

text: Architecture is the result of the state of the spirit of the epoch. We are in the
label: Paragraph

text: face of an international event . . . techniques, problems posed, like scientific
label: Paragraph

text: means, are universal. [lowever, the regions are distinct from each other,
label: Paragraph

text: because climatic conditions, racial currents . . . always guide the solution
label: Paragraph

text: towards forms which they condition.”
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's earliest contact with regional ideas had been in 1910,
label: Paragraph

text: under the influence of Alexandre Cingria-Vaneyre, an advocate of a
label: Paragraph

text: classical, Mediterraneanized Suisse-Romande. With the Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Syndicalists he now encountered similar ideas on a global scale. The
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Syndicalists believed that Europe should be divided into three
label: Paragraph

text: ‘natural’ zones: the Germans in the north-west, the Slavs in the east,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Latin races in the south (including North Africa). Under the
label: Paragraph

text: sway of such racial theories—which were quite common in Europe in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1930s—Le Corbusier began to think in terms of a global modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in which technology would come into direct confronta-
label: Paragraph

text: tion with the natural geographical forces of different macro-regions.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ated a series of urban projects in the developing world, culminating in
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar Germany:
label: Title

text: the Dialectic of the
label: Title

text: Modern 1920-33
label: Title

text: In Germany, as in France, there was a ‘return to order’ after the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War, though it was delayed by political and economic crisis.
label: Paragraph

text: When it came it rejected not just Expressionism but the values of the
label: Paragraph

text: Wilhelmine culture that Expressionism had attacked. Whereas in
label: Paragraph

text: France the return to order, even its progressive form, could be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: re-affirming an established and triumphant national tradition, in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, defeated in the war, it implied a radical break with the
label: Paragraph

text: national past and a search for alternative principles.
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture that began to emerge in Germany around 1922
label: Paragraph

text: reflected a dramatic change of orientation in the visual arts as a whole.
label: Paragraph

text: The movement known as ‘Neue Sachlichkeit’ (New Objectivity’ or
label: Paragraph

text: more accurately ‘ Fact-like-ness’),' was indicative of a new realism. The
label: Paragraph

text: term was first used in 1923 in the context of painting by museum direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tor Gustav Hartlaub, who defined it as ‘realism with a socialist flavour’.
label: Paragraph

text: The movement was sometimes interpreted as a form of cynicism—a
label: Paragraph

text: reaction to the horrors of a disastrous war—and sometimes as a ‘magic
label: Paragraph

text: realism’. The art critic Franz Roh expressed the situation thus: ‘The
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist generation had rightly opposed Impressionism with the
label: Paragraph

text: man of ethical principles . .. The most recent artist corresponds to a
label: Paragraph

text: third type, one who shares Expressionism’s far-sighted aims, but is
label: Paragraph

text: more down-to-earth and knows how to enjoy the present.”
label: Paragraph

text: In architecture, the change was registered by Adolf Behne. As chief
label: Paragraph

text: spokesman of Expressionism and a key figure in the Arbeitsrat fur
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst (AFK), Behne had held strongly anti-technological views, as is
label: Paragraph

text: clear from his essay ‘Die Wiederkehr der Kunst’ (‘The Restoration of
label: Paragraph

text: Art’) of 1919. But by 1922 he had completely reversed his position. In
label: Paragraph

text: his essay of that year, ‘Kunst, Handwerk, Technik’ (‘Art, Craft, and
label: Paragraph

text: Technology’)* he renounced his earlier views, claiming that the divi-
label: Paragraph

text: sion of labour inaugurated by the machine was an improvement on the
label: Paragraph

text: old ‘organic’ relation between the individual craftsman and his
label: Paragraph

text: products, since it brought into play a ‘higher awareness’. After a trans-
label: Paragraph

text: itional period, the worker would come to understand his role within
label: Paragraph

text: the totality of industrialized society. Zivt/isation and Gesellschaft were
label: Paragraph

text: now embraced at the expense of the old paradigms of Kultur and
label: Paragraph

text: Gemeinschaft. Behne’s new concept of the relation between the worker
label: Paragraph

text: and his work was similar to the view that Gropius had already
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in his ‘Kunst und Industriebau’ speech of rgtt in an earlier
label: Paragraph

text: ‘return to order’ (see page 68).
label: Paragraph

text: The Bauhaus: from Expressionism to Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Title

text: When Gropius was appointed to succeed Henry van de Velde as direc-
label: Paragraph

text: tor of the Academy of Fine Art at Weimar in 1919, he was given the
label: Paragraph

text: task of creating a new School of Architecture and Applied Art which
label: Paragraph

text: would unify the Hochshule fiir Bildende Kunst with the recently dis-
label: Paragraph

text: banded Kunstgewerbeshule. The integration of fine arts with crafts was
label: Paragraph

text: standard policy in German art schools at the time.4 But as we have seen
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius had grander ambitions: he wanted the academy (which he now)
label: Paragraph

text: renamed the Bauhaus) to become the spearhead of the AFK’s pro-
label: Paragraph

text: gramme for the transformation of German artistic culture under the
label: Paragraph

text: wing of architecture (sce page 96). This programme was predicated on
label: Paragraph

text: the belief that artistic culture was threatened by the materialism of
label: Paragraph

text: industrial capitalism and could only be saved by a spiritual revolution.
label: Paragraph

text: In the ‘Bauhaus Manifesto’ of 1919, Gropius wrote, in Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: vein, ‘Let us conceive a new building of the future . . . architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: painting, and sculpture rising to Heaven out of the hands of a million
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen, the crystal symbol of the new in the future’ [107].*
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1919 and 1923, however, the Bauhaus abandoned its
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist ideology and began to absorb the ideas of Neue
label: Paragraph

text: During the second half of the nineteenth century there had been
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: countries over the lack of affordable housing for unskilled and semi-
label: Paragraph

text: skilled workers. By 1914 the housing reform movement in Germany
label: Paragraph

text: had gathered considerable momentum and non-profit building
label: Paragraph

text: societies were widespread—even if the results so far were meagre. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1924, therefore, when the Social Democratic Party municipal auth-
label: Paragraph

text: orities put in place their housing programmes, they were able to benefit
label: Paragraph

text: from institutions and powers already in place.’? A remarkable charac-
label: Paragraph

text: teristic of this housing campaign was the extent to which it was
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by the avant-garde, though a precedent for this had been
label: Paragraph

text: set in Holland, where both Berlage and Oud had also received official
label: Paragraph

text: city appointments."
label: Paragraph

text: After the First World War Germany was rich in technically compe-
label: Paragraph

text: tent, ideologically progressive architects, and many of these were put in
label: Paragraph

text: charge of city housing programmes between 1924 and 1931, including
label: Paragraph

text: Otto Haesler (1880-1962) in Celle, Max Berg (1870-1947) in Breslau,
label: Paragraph

text: Fritz Schumacher (1869-1947) in Hamburg, Ernst May (1886-1970) in
label: Paragraph

text: Frankfurt-am-Main, and Martin Wagner (1885-1957) in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Garden Suburbs before the First World War, the post-war
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlungen consisted of enclaves of new housing on the outskirts of
label: Paragraph

text: existing cities. But they differed from the Garden Suburb model in
label: Paragraph

text: several respects. They were, for example, built to higher densities and
label: Paragraph

text: consisted mostly (though not exclusively) of apartment blocks of up to
label: Paragraph

text: five storeys (considered the maximum walk-up height). These were
label: Paragraph

text: generally laid out on the Zei/enbaw principle of parallel blocks aligned
label: Paragraph

text: north-south at right angles to the access street (a system that had
label: Paragraph

text: already been proposed before the war).'* This gave to each apartment
label: Paragraph

text: the fresh air and sunlight that had been conspicuously absent in the
label: Paragraph

text: late-nineteenth-century tenements—the so-called Mietkasernen
label: Paragraph

text: (‘rental barracks’)—with their dark courtyards. At the aesthetic and
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic level, they followed the rules of Neue Sachlichkeit—that is to
label: Paragraph

text: say they were stripped of all ornament and had flat roofs. Ornament
label: Paragraph

text: was replaced by the fairly extensive use of coloured surfaces. Some of
label: Paragraph

text: the larger Sied/ungen included public buildings such as schools and
label: Paragraph

text: hospitals, and the housing was generally provided with public facilities
label: Paragraph

text: such as central heating and laundries.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of the individual apartments reflected the influence o:
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 1890s (see page 50). Erna Mcycr’s highly successful Der Neue Haushalt
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the middle classes even more than the workers.'5

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Functionalists versus rationalists
label: Title

text: One of the main conflicts within the German avant-garde of the 1920s
label: Paragraph

text: was that between the ‘functionalists’ and ‘rationalists’. In one of the
label: Paragraph

text: first attempts to define the Neue Sachlichkeit movement, Der Moderne
label: Paragraph

text: Zweckbau (The Modern Functional Building, written in 1923 but not
label: Paragraph

text: published until 1926), Adolf Behne drew attention to this conflict and
label: Paragraph

text: analysed the ideological differences which underlay it. According to
label: Paragraph

text: Behne, the functionalists (whom he might more accurately have called
label: Paragraph

text: ‘organicists’) created unique, non-repeatable buildings whose forms
label: Paragraph

text: were shaped round their functions, whereas the rationalists looked for
label: Paragraph

text: typical and repeatable forms that were able to fulfil generalized needs.
label: Paragraph

text: Behne equated the functionalists with the ex-Expressionist architects,
label: Paragraph

text: who, under the guise of being true to the laws of nature, in fact created
label: Paragraph

text: singular buildings that were unable to become parts of a greater whole:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘As the functionalist looks for the greatest possible adaptation to the
label: Paragraph

text: most specialized purpose, the rationalist looks for the most appropriate
label: Paragraph

text: solution for many cases.”° The functionalists are individualists, while
label: Paragraph

text: the rationalists accept a responsibility to society.
label: Paragraph

text: Theo van Doesburg, in one of his articles in the journal Her
label: Paragraph

text: Bouwbedrijf,”* made the same distinction as Behne, though he put
label: Paragraph

text: greater stress than Behne on problems of aesthetics. For van Doesburg
label: Paragraph

text: the functionalists, in their search for a close fit between forms and
label: Paragraph

text: functions, ignored the psychological need for ‘spare space’ in buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: and he cited Henri Poincaré’s concept of ‘tactile space’ to support this
label: Paragraph

text: idea.”
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: putting forward two ‘ideal types’, and that actual buildings seldom
label: Paragraph

text: conformed completely to one or the other: the Neue Sachlichkeit ten-
label: Paragraph

text: dency was, by definition, concerned with generic rather than individual
label: Paragraph

text: problems; and even the most extreme Expressionists had, by 1924,
label: Paragraph

text: accepted rationalist principles. However, although the work of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe and the spiritualization of technique
label: Title

text: Although no one architect in the Germany of the 1920s dominated the
label: Paragraph

text: professional scene as Le Corbusier did in France, the reputation of
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe (1886-1969) in the sphere of aesthetics seems to
label: Paragraph

text: have been equal to that of Gropius in the sphere of organization. A
label: Paragraph

text: man of few, if weighty, words, Mies was not only an astute self-
label: Paragraph

text: publicist, but an architect with the ability to reduce every problem toa
label: Paragraph

text: kind of essential simplicity—a simplicity that continues to give rise to
label: Paragraph

text: conflicting interpretations of his work to this day.
label: Paragraph

text: In Mies’s work, two opposing tendencies struggled for dominance.
label: Paragraph

text: One could be described as the enclosure of function in a generalized
label: Paragraph

text: cubic container not committed to any particular set of concrete func-
label: Paragraph

text: tions—a tendency partly derived from his early allegiance to
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassicism. The other was the articulation of the building in
label: Paragraph

text: response to the fluidity of life. This second tendency, however, seldom
label: Paragraph

text: involved him in figural shaping, as it did the Expressionists, nor did it
label: Paragraph

text: align Mies with what Behne called ‘functionalism’. Following a

text: Between 1931 and 1935, Mies designed a series of houses which

label: Paragraph

text: House (1935), for single-storey houses within closed courts. These
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde architects of the 1930s—in this respect Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: also suggest that Mies (or his clients) might have been withdrawing
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: situation. In spite of this tendency towards enclosure, however, the
label: Paragraph

text: more elaborate projects of this period, such as the Hubbe House, were
label: Paragraph

text: left partially open to give framed views of nature [123, 124]. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: the natural landscape is omnipresent in Mies’s sketches at this (ime,
label: Paragraph

text: suggesting that the main function of the house had become that of
label: Paragraph

text: framing a view in which nature is idealized. Mies later acknowledged
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: According to a common misconception, Mies’s minimalist distilla-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of architecture was the result of a deep engagement with the craft
label: Paragraph

text: of building. Certainly, Mies was obsessed by certain craft-like aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture, but he was more concerned with idealizing and medi-
label: Paragraph

text: ating techniques of graphic representation than with construction. As
label: Paragraph

text: is clear from his writings, Mies realized that the traditional relation-
label: Paragraph

text: ship between the craftsman and his product had been destroyed by the
label: Paragraph

text: machine. His criteria were ideal and visual, not constructional—not
label: Paragraph

text: even ‘visual-constructional’. It is true that unlike, for instance, Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, Mies displays the materiality of his building elements, but
label: Paragraph

text: he assembles these elements like montages; their connections are never
label: Paragraph

text: visible. Even more than that of the other Modernists, Mies’s work runs
label: Paragraph

text: counter to the ‘tectonic’ tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Recently, in a justified reaction against the myth of Mies-the-
label: Paragraph

text: constructor, critics have invented a Post-Modern Mies—one who
label: Paragraph

text: primarily operated with surfaces and effects, within the endless play of
label: Paragraph

text: the signifier.?? But this interpretation errs in the opposite direction. It
label: Paragraph

text: ignores Mies’s fear of post-Nietzschean chaos and it also assumes that
label: Paragraph

text: an aesthetic of materials and their ephemeral appearance (as signified
label: Paragraph

text: by the German word Schein) is incompatible with a belief in founda-
label: Paragraph

text: tional values. Mies’s conception of architecture followed the dialectical
label: Paragraph

text: tendency of German Idealism to think in terms of opposites.
label: Paragraph

text: According to the Neoplatonic aesthetics that influenced his thinking,
label: Paragraph

text: the transcendental world is reflected in the world of the senses (Mies
label: Paragraph

text: was fond of quoting St Augustine’s dictum: “Beauty is the radiance of
label: Paragraph

text: truth’). When modified by the concept of the ‘will of the epoch’, this
label: Paragraph

text: became the basis of his belief that the spiritual could only become
label: Paragraph

text: active in the world in a historicized form, that is to say in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: technology. Such problems of surface and depth, the contingent and
label: Paragraph

text: the ideal, also lay behind the anti-formalism of Mies’s articles in G in
label: Paragraph

text: 1923. These did not represent a ‘materialist’ phase (later to be abjured)
label: Paragraph

text: as most commentators claim; they reflected a topos of Modernist aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetics derived from German Romanticism, according to which the
label: Paragraph

text: forms of art should, like those of nature, reveal an inner essence and not
label: Paragraph

text: be imposed from the outside.*!
label: Paragraph

text: To enquire into Mies’s philosophical background is, of course, in no
label: Paragraph

text: way to suggest that his architecture was an ‘expression’ of philosophical
label: Paragraph

text: ideas. For Mies, it was precisely the auto-referentiality of the work of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that gave it access to the world of spiritual meaning. Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism and his idealism were perfectly compatible.

text: Published in nine issues between 1924 and 1928, the journal was edited

text: Stam, and the Russian El Lissitzky (who ceased to be an editor when
label: Paragraph

text: he was expelled from Switzerland in 1925). The Swiss architect Hannes
label: Paragraph

text: Meyer (1889-1954) was also closely connected with ABC. The original
label: Paragraph

text: impetus for the group’s formation came from Swiss-Dutch connec-
label: Paragraph

text: tions that had been forged by two architects of the older generation,
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Moser (1860-1936) and H. P. Berlage, and the interest on the part
label: Paragraph

text: of young Swiss architects in Berlage’s plan for South Amsterdam.
label: Paragraph

text: The group was strongly opposed to De Stijl’s idealist and aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: approach. As Jacques Gubler has observed: ‘Where De Stijl postulated
label: Paragraph

text: the absolute of art and elementary form, ABC postulated the absolute
label: Paragraph

text: of technique and material.’ ABC believed that only a ‘dictatorship’ of
label: Paragraph

text: science and technology would be able to satisfy the collective needs of
label: Paragraph

text: society.** There are obvious connections between this philosophy and
label: Paragraph

text: that of the Constructivist First Working Group in Soviet Russia (see
label: Paragraph

text: pages 123-5).
label: Paragraph

text: In their projects, Mart Stam and Hans Schmidt were primarily
label: Paragraph

text: interested in systems of prefabrication, particularly in reinforced con-
label: Paragraph

text: crete. Despite their anti-art stand, their main concern was to develop
label: Paragraph

text: an architectural ‘language’ which reflected serial production. Their
label: Paragraph

text: discourse was not essentially different from that of Neue Sachlichkeit
label: Paragraph

text: as a whole but it claimed to be more scientifically rigorous. Stam’s
label: Paragraph

text: researches into prefabrication included ‘reinterpretations’ of Mies van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe’s glass skyscraper of 1921-2 and Concrete Office Building of
label: Caption

text: 1922 [125].*> Stam adapted Mies’s ideas to the needs of mass produc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion, for example the curvilinear plan of the glass skyscraper was
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into a circle, and the two-way structure of the office build-
label: Paragraph

text: ing into a linear, additive structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Hannes Meyer’s theoretical position was also close to that of the
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist Left. He claimed that architecture was merely one
label: Paragraph

text: instance of the technical-productive process: “The depreciation of all
label: Paragraph

text: art works is an indisputable fact, and there is no doubt that their
label: Paragraph

text: replacement with a new exact science is merely a matter of time. . . art
label: Paragraph

text: is becoming invention and controlled reality.’ His early work—par-
label: Paragraph

text: ticularly the Freidorf-Siedlung near Basel (1919-21)—was in the
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical style typical of the Swiss Garden City movement, in
label: Paragraph

text: which he played an active part. After his rather late conversion to
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism in 1924, the projects he undertook with Hans Wittwer
label: Paragraph

text: Two progressive movements in architecture made their appearance in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Plastici movement in painting, which took its point of departure from
label: Paragraph

text: the metaphysical realism of Giorgio de Chirico.
label: Paragraph

text: The first of the movements was the ‘Novecento’, which emerged
label: Paragraph

text: towards the end of the war. This was a ‘moderate’ avant-garde that had
label: Paragraph

text: much in common with the German Biedermeier movement of a few
label: Paragraph

text: years earlier, It promoted an architecture which, though ‘modern’,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: work is notable for, among other things, its complex interplay of

text: In 1934 Mussolini himself belatedly announced his support of the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Post-war reconstruction
label: Title

text: Under Fascism the development of an international Modernism had
label: Paragraph

text: been relatively free of political interference, despite antagonistic ele-
label: Paragraph

text: ments within the Fascist Party. Therefore there was considerable
label: Paragraph

text: continuity between pre-war and post-war architecture in Italy. But
label: Paragraph

text: paradoxically there were also strong revisionist pressures. Since most
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist architects in Italy had been keen supporters of Fascism, the
label: Paragraph

text: profession was driven, after the defeat of Fascism, to search for a new
label: Paragraph

text: architectural identity. Architects became engaged in a succession of
label: Paragraph

text: ideological debates which opened up the Modernist tradition to new
label: Paragraph

text: interpretations.’ In these debates Milan and Rome represented oppo-
label: Paragraph

text: site poles. The Milanese architects continued the pre-war rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: programme established by Persico and Pagano, associating rationalism
label: Paragraph

text: with leftist politics.*
label: Paragraph

text: In Rome, where rationalism had never been a strong force, a cri-
label: Paragraph

text: tique of the rationalists was mounted by the architect-critic Bruno
label: Paragraph

text: Zevi (1918-2000). In two books, Towards an Organic Architecture (1945)
label: Paragraph

text: and A History of Modern Architecture (1950), he called for a more
label: Paragraph

text: humane architecture that would follow the examples of Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright and Alvar Aalto. Zevi’s Association for Organic Architecture
label: Caption

text: announced the promotion of ‘an architecture for the human being. . .
label: Paragraph

text: shaped to the human scale and satisfying the spiritual and psycholog-
label: Paragraph

text: ical needs of man in society . . . organic architecture is therefore the
label: Paragraph

text: antithesis of a monumental architecture used to create official myths’.”
label: Paragraph

text: In its attack on the architecture of the Fascist era, Zevi’s critique was
label: Paragraph

text: aimed at both neoclassicism and rationalism. But he shared most of the
label: Paragraph

text: ideals of the rationalists, particularly that of creating a genuincly
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture in which social progress and technical innovation
label: Title

text: would go hand in hand. These hopes were shattered when, in 1948, at
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of the Cold War, the centre-right Christian Democrats
label: Paragraph

text: were returned to power, Far from inaugurating a programme of social
label: Paragraph

text: reform and technical modernization, the government concentrated on
label: Paragraph

text: shoring up the tangle of existing intcrest groups within the construc-
label: Paragraph

text: tion industry. In 1949 it created INA Casa (the Institute of Home
label: Paragraph

text: Insurance), with the aim of making ‘provisions for increasing worker
label: Paragraph

text: employment, facilitating the construction of workers’ housing’.* The
label: Paragraph

text: ptiority given to reducing unemployment had the effect of inhibiting
label: Paragraph

text: technical advance in an industry still largely at a pre-industrial level.”

label: Title

text: If the Neorealist movement marks the first appearance of what Vittorio
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ture, the same striving can be found in l’rnesto Rogers’s concept of an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that responds to its urban context. In an article in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary Building Practice’ Rogers (1909-69) advocated an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture which, while remaining explicitly modern in its
label: Paragraph

text: techniques, would respond formally to its historical and spatial
label: Paragraph

text: context—an architecture based on an existential rather than an
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: (b. 1913). Neoliberty was concerned neither with the immediate

text: The dialectic of rationalism and organicism
label: Title

text: For a number of architects, breaking with the straitjacket of the ration-
label: Paragraph

text: alist tradition did not entail any stylistic negotiations with history. Like
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Autostrada del Sole near Florence (1960-4) | 130], he created an iso-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: also makes an oblique reference to Le Corbusier’s chapel at
label: Paragraph

text: Ronchamp). The hermetic and intensely private work of Carlo Scarpa
label: Paragraph

text: (1902-78) contrasts sharply with Michelucci’s public rhetoric. Scarpa’s
label: Paragraph

text: subtle museum designs, such as the Gipsoteca Canoviana in Possagno,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: BPR—made their own.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Anew urban dimension
label: Title

text: At the end of the 1950s the attitude of Italian architect-planners to the
label: Paragraph

text: problem of the city underwent an important shift. Demographic
label: Paragraph

text: movements due to south-north migration as well as technical develop-
label: Paragraph

text: ments in the building industry led to a redefinition of the scope of
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning, now seen to embrace larger ‘city regions’. According to
label: Paragraph

text: Manfredo Tafuri:
label: Title

text: Italian intellectuals were becoming aware of a new reality; convulsive urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ization and the diffusion of mass communication had effected profound
label: Paragraph

text: transformations in society. These changes, along with rapid economic growth,
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged the formation of interpretative models that quickly replaced those
label: Paragraph

text: of the preceding decade . . . Neorealist myths were replaced by technological
label: Paragraph

text: ones... The entire concept of urban planning would be overhauled in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 19608.
label: Paragraph

text: The concept of the ‘city region’, seen as a set of dynamic relations in a
label: Paragraph

text: state of constant change, took the place of the fixed model.¥
label: Paragraph

text: Anessential precondition of this concept was the revalidation of the
label: Paragraph

text: city as such. In 1959 the architect Giuseppe Samona (1898-1983) pub-
label: Paragraph

text: lished a book entitled Urbanism and the Future of the City in which he
label: Paragraph

text: defended the big city and attacked the social assumptions of the
label: Paragraph

text: Garden City movement and the Anglo-American concept of the
label: Title

text: small-town neighbourhood that had dominated Italian urban theory
label: Paragraph

text: since the war. At the same time a number of competitions were held for
label: Paragraph

text: the design of new business and administrative centres to be inserted
label: Paragraph

text: within existing cities. The first and most influential of such projects
label: Paragraph

text: was Quaroni’s design for the Quartiere Cepalle Barene di S. Giuliano
label: Caption

text: in Mestre (1959) [131], in which the city fabric, free to develop with the
label: Paragraph

text: minimum of planning constraints, was given focus by a monumental
label: Paragraph

text: group of buildings facing the lagoon. In this and similar projects, the
label: Paragraph

text: city was conceived as two parts, one fixed and symbolic, the other con-
label: Paragraph

text: tinuously changing and essentially uncontrollable.“
label: Paragraph

text: In other contemporaneous projects, this dualistic concept was given

text: Scandinavia 1910—65
label: Title

text: After the Second World War, the Modern Movement became identi-
label: Paragraph

text: fied with the victorious democracies and was adopted by the
label: Paragraph

text: professional establishments in Europe and America. With the emer-
label: Paragraph

text: gence of the welfare state in Western Europe, a new concept of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘planning’ took shape—one compatible with liberal democracy and
label: Paragraph

text: based on Keynesian economic doctrine.’ The chief model for this
label: Paragraph

text: combination of planning and capitalism was to be found in the
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavian countries. Sweden in particular became a role model for
label: Paragraph

text: many architects in Western Europe and America. In order to under-
label: Paragraph

text: stand the nature of this influence it will be necessary to trace the
label: Paragraph

text: development of architecture in Scandinavia since just before the First
label: Paragraph

text: World War.
label: Paragraph

text: From neoclassicism to Modernism in Denmark and Sweden
label: Title

text: The European neoclassical movement of the first decade of the twenti-
label: Paragraph

text: eth century had a strong impact in Scandinavia, whose architects came
label: Paragraph

text: under the spell of the German Biedermeier revival disseminated by
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Mebes, Paul Schultze-Naumburg, and Heinrich Tessenow. The
label: Paragraph

text: initial impulse for this tendency came from Denmark, where architects
label: Paragraph

text: had been studying such neoclassical predecessors as H. C. Hansen
label: Paragraph

text: since the 1880s.” Danish and Swedish architects became fascinated by
label: Paragraph

text: their own vernacular and classical traditions as exemplified in
label: Paragraph

text: sixteenth-century castles, Baroque palaces, and_carly-nineteenth-
label: Title

text: century neoclassical buildings. An eclectic neoclassicism that
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed from local traditions, German eighteenth-century vernacu-
label: Paragraph

text: lar classicism, Friedrich Gilly (1772-1800), Claude-Nicolas Ledoux,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Tuscan Renaissance, dominated Scandinavian architecture
label: Paragraph

text: from the First World War to the late 1920s. The severe Doricist
label: Paragraph

text: museum in Faborg (1912-15) by Carl Petersen (1874-1923) set the tone
label: Paragraph

text: of the entire movement.
label: Paragraph

text: In Germany, Expressionism intervened between neoclassicism and
label: Paragraph

text: the New Objectivity, but in Scandinavia there was a direct transition
label: Paragraph

text: from one to the other, revealing their similarities rather than their dif-
label: Paragraph

text: ferences. Both Denmark and Sweden inaugurated programmes of
label: Paragraph

text: state-sponsored housing during the First World War to meet a
label: Paragraph

text: housing shortage that had been particularly acute in Scandinavia. At
label: Paragraph

text: that time the model being used for urban housing was that of eigh-
label: Paragraph

text: teenth-century perimeter blocks. The clearest examples of the
label: Paragraph

text: transition from this model to Modernism can be seen in Denmark, in
label: Paragraph

text: the Hans Tavsensgade project in Norrebro (1919) by Paul Baumann
label: Caption

text: (1887-1963), where perimeter housing encloses a central communal
label: Paragraph

text: garden.’ With the new ideology of science and hygiene, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: progressive opening up of the courtyard to the outside, as in the Ved
label: Paragraph

text: Classens Have project in Copenhagen (1924-9) by Carl Petersen and
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Baumann.‘ Eventually, as in Blidah Park (1932-4) by Ivar Bentsen
label: Caption

text: (1876-1943), the perimeter block disappeared altogether, to be replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by linear bars set in parkland.’ At the same time the regularly pierced
label: Paragraph

text: classical wall surface gave way to the free facade, even when load-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing wall construction was still in use. Unlike Germany in the
label: Paragraph

text: 19208, however, hybrid, semi-enclosed layouts immediately appeared,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the Bellavista Estate at Klampenborg near Copenhagen (1934-7)
label: Paragraph

text: by Arne Jacobsen (1902-71).°
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: credit, including the rustic—classical Woodland Chapel at the
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery of Enskede in Stockholm (1918-20)’ and the Ledoux-like
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Modern Movement in Sweden
label: Title

text: Social reform and housing
label: Title

text: In Sweden, the new architecture was, from the start, closely identified
label: Paragraph

text: with the social reform movement—just as it had been some ten years
label: Paragraph

text: before in Germany. In 1932 the Social Democrats came to power and
label: Paragraph

text: instituted a series of reforms inspired by Prime Minister Per Albin
label: Paragraph

text: Hansen's slogan comparing the state to ‘the house of the people’
label: Paragraph

text: (Folkhemmet).® These reforms were carried out within a liberal democ-
label: Paragraph

text: racy, but facilitated by a long tradition of state interventionism. At
label: Paragraph

text: their core was the housing programme. During the 1920s a vigorous
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative movement had paved the way for legislation which was to
label: Paragraph

text: result, after 1945, in a fully fledged welfare state. Housing built by the
label: Paragraph

text: cooperatives (which often had their own architectural departments)
label: Paragraph

text: was extremely influential in the spread of Modernist architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden—for example the layout of the Kvarnholmen Company
label: Paragraph

text: housing project by the architects of the KV cooperative’ was to be
label: Paragraph

text: widely imitated abroad.
label: Paragraph

text: Systems design
label: Title

text: During the 1960s and 1970s there was a dramatic increase in housing
label: Paragraph

text: production in Sweden. A programme was instituted which aimed at
label: Paragraph

text: providing one million dwellings between 1965 and 1974.° Within this
label: Paragraph

text: programme, 40 per cent of dwellings took the form of high-rise, high-
label: Paragraph

text: density projects, using a ‘Systems’ approach to planning and
label: Paragraph

text: construction. This approach maximized the use of standardized parts
label: Paragraph

text: and large-scale prefabrication, and was modelled on the technique of
label: Paragraph

text: Systems engineering used by the United States defence industry.’ The
label: Paragraph

text: approach was not restricted to Sweden. In Denmark—to speak of
label: Paragraph

text: Scandinavia alone—there was also a technically driven development in
label: Paragraph

text: mass housing which resulted in dense, high-rise projects such as that of
label: Paragraph

text: Hoje Gladsaxe (1960-7o).””
label: Paragraph

text: In the late 1960s there was growing public opposition to this kind of
label: Paragraph

text: development, which was often unsatisfactory even at a purely technical
label: Paragraph

text: level. This reaction, which was exacerbated by the fall-out from the
label: Paragraph

text: French student revolt of 1968, was to lead to revisions in government
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: increasing exclusion by the building industry, architects tended to react
label: Paragraph

text: in one of two ways: either by accepting technological developments
label: Paragraph

text: and trying to take control of them; or by retreating into a world of one-
label: Paragraph

text: off projects of modest scale, where the economics of mass production
label: Paragraph

text: and mass consumption did not apply.

text: The Modern Movement in Finland

label: Title

text: In 1904 the critic-architects Sigurd Frosterus and Gustav Strengell

label: Paragraph

text: Opponents’, criticizing the result of the competition for Helsinki
label: Paragraph

text: Railway Station (1906-16), which had been won by Eliel Saarinen with
label: Paragraph

text: a late-Jugendstil design. The pamphlet attacked national romanti-
label: Paragraph

text: cism—which had been closely associated with Finnish national
label: Paragraph

text: liberation—proposing in its place an architecture that was rationalist
label: Paragraph

text: and internationalist. In response to this criticism the final versions of
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s design for the station and Lars Sonck’s design for the Stock
label: Paragraph

text: Exchange (1911) were both modified. This turn to a structurally expres-
label: Paragraph

text: sive rationalism based on the teachings of Viollet-le-Duc was,
label: Paragraph

text: however, short-lived. It was soon overtaken by the Swedish-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: neoclassical movement. Like rationalism, this movement was opposed
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: posed were formal and classical rather than structural.

text: Alvar Aalto and the New Objectivity
label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: (1891-1955) and Alvar Aalto (1898-1976) stand out. Their joint entry for
label: Paragraph

text: the Turku Fair competition of 1929 is widely seen as having introduced
label: Paragraph

text: the new movement to the Finnish public.
label: Paragraph

text: Alvar Aalto soon emerged as the leader of the group with his com-
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: and the Tuberculosis Sanatorium in Paimio (1929-33) [136, 137]. The
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: though it retained the ghost of its original Beaux-Arts plan. Paimio
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Urbanism and housing in late Le Corbusier
label: Title

text: After his 1929 lecture tour of South America, Le Corbusier became
label: Paragraph

text: involved in a series of urban projects that were very different from his
label: Paragraph

text: previous city plans. Whereas the Ville Radieuse had been a schematic
label: Paragraph

text: design for an ideal site, the projects for Rio de Janeiro (1929) and the
label: Paragraph

text: “‘Obus’ (‘explosive shell’) plans for the city of Algiers (1932-42) were
label: Paragraph

text: intended for actual sites. They were also closely linked to Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's new-found interest in /’2omme réel and regional cultures
label: Paragraph

text: based on local customs and geographies. In these projects modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and engineering extend their reach to vast colonial and
label: Paragraph

text: post-colonial territories and assume a new cosmological significance in
label: Paragraph

text: their struggle with primordial nature.
label: Paragraph

text: In Rio and Algiers Le Corbusier did not abandon his earlier urban-
label: Paragraph

text: ism, but its forms became more sensitive to local topographies, and
label: Paragraph

text: there is a greater absorption of private life by monumental, collective
label: Paragraph

text: forms. Already in 1922, the Ville Contemporaine had envisaged a new
label: Paragraph

text: integration of private and collective life. For example, public circula-
label: Paragraph

text: tion was seen as a single system, with the corridors serving the flats
label: Paragraph

text: becoming streets-in-the-air replacing access roads. In the Rio and
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers plans the integration of circulation and housing became the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant theme. Housing was slung under a viaduct carrying the main
label: Paragraph

text: highway, recalling the ‘Roadtown’ project of 1910 by the American
label: Paragraph

text: architect Edgar Chambless [144]. In Algiers, the housing viaduct
label: Caption

text: followed a long sinuous route along the coast, while a separate group of
label: Paragraph

text: apartments—through which another road was cut at mid-level—was
label: Paragraph

text: sited further inland on the Fort de ’Empereur hills, connected by a
label: Paragraph

text: high-level viaduct to the business centre at the port, the ‘cité d affaires’.
label: Caption

text: Roads and housing were treated as a single, integrated system. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the most interesting aspects of the project is the separation of infra-
label: Paragraph

text: structure and infill, allowing the inhabitants to build their own houses
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's Algiers project coincided with growing public pres-

label: Paragraph

text: several years."

text: It was while working on these that Le Corbusier developed the idea

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the plasticity and play of scale that had been sacrificed with the sup-
label: Paragraph

text: pression of structure. Nothing shows more clearly the similarities and
label: Paragraph

text: differences between Le Corbusier and the Beaux-Arts. In his final
label: Paragraph

text: version of the Algiers office tower Le Corbusier reverts to a primitive

label: Caption

text: In 1945, Raoul Dautry, Minister of Reconstruction in the first post-
label: Paragraph

text: war French government, commissioned Le Corbusier to build a unité
label: Paragraph

text: d@ habitation (approximately: ‘unit of housing’) in Marseilles.’ The key
label: Paragraph

text: concept was that the structure should be large enough to incorporate
label: Paragraph

text: the communal services required to support the daily lives of its inhabi-
label: Paragraph

text: tants. The idea of such a collective was not new: examples were to be
label: Paragraph

text: found in the Soviet Union and Sweden dating from the 1930s. Where
label: Paragraph

text: the completed Unité d’Habitation (1946-52) differed from these was in
label: Paragraph

text: its strong monumental presence. Although clearly influenced by such
label: Paragraph

text: Russian schemes as the Vesnin brothers’ communal housing project for
label: Paragraph

text: Kusnetsk of 1930,° the building does not reflect the Vesnins’ socialist
label: Paragraph

text: agenda. According to Le Corbusier it was the culmination of his
label: Paragraph

text: ‘concept of modern middle-class housing’.* It is closer to Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Fourier’s ideal collective palace, the phalanstére (which similarly had a
label: Paragraph

text: population of 1,800), a Carthusian monastery, or a transatlantic liner—
label: Paragraph

text: all of them self-contained communities. Internally, Le Corbusier used
label: Paragraph

text: a modified version of the interlocking duplex apartments first pro-
label: Paragraph

text: posed for the Ville Contemporaine in 1922. Externally a system of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete sun-breakers, doubling as loggias and derived from the
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers office tower, made legible the internal spaces. Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: described the Algiers office tower as ‘a palace, no longer a box—a
label: Paragraph

text: palace worthy of reigning over the landscape’.* He could equally well
label: Paragraph

text: have been describing the Unité.
label: Paragraph

text: Comparing Le Corbusier’s Unité d’Habitation with his housing at
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers we see that they represent two very different concepts. While
label: Paragraph

text: the Unité is a discrete whole, designed to the last detail by the architect,
label: Paragraph

text: Algiers is an endless infrastructure with random infill. A similar differ-
label: Paragraph

text: ence existed between two new urban concepts that emerged during
label: Paragraph

text: and after the Second World War, both of which challenged the ortho-
label: Paragraph

text: doxies of the rationalist tradition. The first was that of the New
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentality, the second the rather complex urban philosophy of
label: Paragraph

text: Team X.
label: Paragraph

text: The New Monumentality
label: Title

text: The idea of a New Monumentality was formulated by the older gener-
label: Paragraph

text: ation of modern architects in Europe and America in the 1940s.
label: Paragraph

text: Already, in the mid-1930s, there had been a call by architects to re-
label: Paragraph

text: introduce the concept of the monument into the Modernist canon. By
label: Paragraph

text: ‘monument’ they did not mean ‘memorial’ in the strict etymological
label: Paragraph

text: sense, but the broader idea, introduced around the turn of the twenti-
label: Paragraph

text: eth century, of representative as opposed to utilitarian buildings. In
label: Paragraph

text: Europe the concept was certainly influenced by the return to classi-
label: Paragraph

text: cism in Nazi Germany and Stalinist Russia, but for the Modernists a
label: Paragraph

text: return to monumentality meant a return to underlying principles not
label: Paragraph

text: to a specific style, and the debate remained at a somewhat abstract
label: Paragraph

text: level.6 One of the most striking post-war examples of such a non-
label: Caption

text: historicist monumentality was Ie Corbusier's Pilgrimage Church of
label: Paragraph

text: Notre-Dame-du-Haut at Ronchamp (1951-5).
label: Caption

text: It was only in the 1940s that the proponents of a New
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentality began to connect it with a specific set of social and
label: Paragraph

text: political ideas. This happened when American Modernists re-identi-
label: Paragraph

text: fied the monument with democracy—just as their predecessors had at
label: Paragraph

text: the time of the City Beautiful movement. The context of this re-
label: Paragraph

text: evaluation was the American government's New Deal building
label: Paragraph

text: programme, which included the Tennessee Valley Authority. In 1941,
label: Paragraph

text: the architect George [lowe declared: ‘The power plants and living
label: Paragraph

text: centres of TVA are an cffort to carve a new pattern of life out of earth,
label: Paragraph

text: air, and water... and make the land the likeness of the people so that
label: Paragraph

text: the people can come to be a likeness of the land.” Three years later,
label: Paragraph

text: Elizabeth Mock, a curator of architecture at the Museum of Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Art in New York, wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: A democracy needs monuments, even though its requirements are not those
label: Paragraph

text: of a dictatorship. There must be occasional buildings which raise the everyday
label: Paragraph

text: casualness of living to a higher and more cercmonial plane, buildings which
label: Paragraph

text: give dignified and coherent form to that interdependence of the individual
label: Paragraph

text: and the social group which is the very nature of democracy.*
label: Paragraph

text: In 1943, Sigfried Giedion—then in exile in the United States—entered
label: Paragraph

text: the debate. In collaboration with the French painter Fernand Léger
label: Paragraph

text: and the Catalan architect Josep Lluis Sert (1902-83) he wrote a mani-
label: Paragraph

text: festo entitled ‘Nine Points on Monumentality’,” and followed it up
label: Paragraph

text: with an essay called ‘The Need for a New Monumentality’.'" In this
label: Paragraph

text: essay, Giedion focused on the need for civic centres symbolizing the
label: Paragraph

text: idea of ‘community’ in which all the visual arts would collaborate,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a new Gesamtkunstwerk. His concept of ‘community’ is
label: Paragraph

text: different from that of Howe and Mock. It does not invoke the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: democracy, but rather—at least by implication—the German concept
label: Paragraph

text: of Volk. His description of the civic centre reminds one of Taut’s
label: Paragraph

text: Volkhaus, though his more immediate source is Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: According to Giedion: ‘Only the imagination of real creators is suited
label: Paragraph

text: to building the lacking civic centres, to instil once more in the public
label: Paragraph

text: the old love of festivals, and to incorporate all the new materials, move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment, colour, and technical possibilities. Who else could utilize them
label: Paragraph

text: for opening up new ways to invigorate the masses?”
label: Paragraph

text: In Le Corbusier's work, the civic centre makes its first tentative
label: Paragraph

text: appearance in 1934 with the projects for the Radiant Farm and the city
label: Paragraph

text: of Némours in North Africa. One year earlicr Sert had planned the
label: Paragraph

text: new industrial town of Cidade dos Motores near Rio de Janeiro. The
label: Paragraph

text: distinctly Corbusian buildings of its civic centre are arranged to form a
label: Paragraph

text: semi-enclosed square reminiscent of an Iberian Plaza Mayor. As if in
label: Paragraph

text: response Le Corbusier, in his civic centre for St. Dié of 1946, included a
label: Paragraph

text: loosely defined square. In this project the group of buildings forming
label: Paragraph

text: the civic centre includes a wnité d'habitation, clearly indicating Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's intention of giving monumental status to housing.

text: The city of Brasilia has to be seen in the context of the unique devel-
label: Paragraph

text: opment of Modernism in Brazil. The Modern Movement was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: elected president. Above all, it was Le Corbusier's rhetorical language
label: Paragraph

text: that appealed to the Brazilian architects. It was as if the force of an idea
label: Paragraph

text: could give instant birth to the new architecture and charge it with
label: Paragraph

text: popular symbolism. Among the many impressive public buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: which the language of Le Corbusier was adapted to Brazilian condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions, the Ministry of Education and Public Health in Rio (1936-45) is
label: Paragraph

text: outstanding [149]. Designed by a team which included Liicio Costa
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier himself, the building broke with the universal perimeter
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: centre of the block. In its diagrammatic separation of offices and col-
label: Paragraph

text: lective functions this building seemed to many—even in Europe—a
label: Paragraph

text: more perfect realization of Corbusian ideas than Le Corbusicr’s own
label: Paragraph

text: public buildings, constrained as they often were by odd-shaped urban
label: Paragraph

text: sites. :

text: CIAM and Team X
label: Title

text: After the Second World War the urban doctrine tacitly accepted by
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the Modern Movement was that promoted by the
label: Paragraph

text: Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne (CLAM). CIAM
label: Caption

text: had been founded in 1928 as the international platform of the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement, which at that time was still opposed by large sections of
label: Paragraph

text: the profession. Branches were quickly formed in the different coun-
label: Paragraph

text: tries of Western Europe and America. The first meeting was held at La
label: Paragraph

text: Sarraz, Switzerland, in the chateau of Fléléne de Mandrot, a wealthy
label: Caption

text: patroness of the arts who had been a keen supporter of Art Deco until
label: Paragraph

text: persuaded by Le Corbusier and Sigfried Giedion to take up the cause
label: Paragraph

text: of modern architecture (and who was to commission a house from Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier at Le Pradet near Toulon the following year).'° Four further
label: Paragraph

text: meetings were to take place before the Second World War. Housing
label: Paragraph

text: and urbanism soon became the main focus of discussion at these con-
label: Paragraph

text: gresses. The early debates reflected the conflict between the leftists,
label: Paragraph

text: who saw the movement as an arm of the socialist revolution, and the
label: Paragraph

text: liberals for whom the aims of the movement were primarily cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and technical. After 1930, when most of the leftists moved to Russia,
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM became increasingly dominated by Le Corbusier and the
label: Paragraph

text: general secretary of the organization, Sigfried Giedion.
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM urban doctrine became enshrined in the ‘Charte d’Athénes’
label: Paragraph

text: (Athens Charter’). Published by I.e Corbusier in 1942, while France
label: Paragraph

text: was under German occupation, this document was Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: heavily edited version of the unpublished proceedings of the fourth
label: Caption

text: CIAM meeting, which had taken place on the SS Patris en route trom
label: Paragraph

text: Marseilles to Athens in 1933. Most of the book was a restatement of
label: Paragraph

text: commonplaces so general as to be acceptable to almost anyone, but it
label: Paragraph

text: was strictly rationalistic and analytical in tone and was based on a clas-
label: Paragraph

text: sificatory system that divided the city into four watertight functions:
label: Paragraph

text: living, working, recreation, and circulation. This Cartesian and for-
label: Paragraph

text: malistic approach to the complex problems of the city was
label: Paragraph

text: unacceptable to younger members of CIAM who joined after the war.
label: Paragraph

text: In spite of the ideas reflected in the Athens Charter, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: himself, as we have seen, had been moving steadily away from his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier rationalism, although he had never fully disavowed it. It was
label: Paragraph

text: this ambiguity that allowed him to remain an important figure for the
label: Paragraph

text: post-war generation, who felt that his ideas had been trivialized by
label: Paragraph

text: most of the second generation of modern architects—those born in the
label: Paragraph

text: first decade of the twentieth century. A sort of alliance was formed
label: Paragraph

text: between Le Corbusier and the young members, who began—with Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's complicity—to play a dominant role in CLAM discussions
label: Paragraph

text: from the ninth congress at Aix-en-Provence (1953) onwards. In 1954,
label: Paragraph

text: after the Dutch ‘Doorn Group’ had explicitly repudiated the Athens
label: Paragraph

text: Charter, the CIAM council entrusted an enlarged Doorn Group with
label: Paragraph

text: the organization of the tenth CIAM meeting, to be held in Dubrovnik
label: Paragraph

text: in 1956. At this point, the Doorn-based group started calling itself
label: Paragraph

text: “Team X’.'6
label: Caption

text: Dubrovnik was to be the last meeting of CIAM in its old form. Asa
label: Paragraph

text: In 1952 the Dutch architect Wim van Bodegraven underlined the need

text: Megastructures
label: Title

text: The Megastructural movement, which was contemporaneous with
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch Structuralism, was not concerned with fixed, recognizable
label: Paragraph

text: units. It was posited on a built environment without cultural norms
label: Paragraph

text: and in a continuous state of flux. In a publication of 1964, the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Fumihiko Maki (b. 1928), onc of the original members of the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolists, distinguished between three types of what he called ‘col-
label: Paragraph

text: lective form’: firstly, Compositional form—in which there is a fixed
label: Paragraph

text: relation between different pre-formed buildings (this is the classical
label: Paragraph

text: way of achieving collective form and includes the civic centre at St. Dié
label: Paragraph

text: by Le Corbusier and that of Brasilia by Niemeyer); secondly,
label: Paragraph

text: Megastructural form—a large frame in which all the functions ofa city
label: Paragraph

text: are housed (this involves the coexistence of structures with different
label: Paragraph

text: rates of obsolescence); and thirdly, Group form—an additive collec-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of typologically similar building units (characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: ‘unplanned’ vernacular villages).
label: Paragraph

text: Within this broad classification, ‘Megastructural form’ presents an
label: Paragraph

text: array of different approaches. A very broad distinction can be made
label: Paragraph

text: between projects which stress the long-term elements and those which
label: Paragraph

text: stress the variable elements—a matter of emphasis, since examples of
label: Paragraph

text: flexible and fixed elements occur in both groups. Within the first cate-
label: Paragraph

text: gory the Japanese Metabolists and the British Archigram will be
label: Paragraph

text: discussed.

text: Constant’s city [143 (see page 208), 159] is based on a long-term
label: Paragraph

text: prognosis of modern society. His writings predict a world in which
label: Paragraph

text: nature will have been totally superseded by technology, fixed commu-
label: Paragraph

text: nities by nomadic flows, work by leisure. In his city, production and
label: Paragraph

text: mechanical transportation (which are said to have destroyed social life
label: Paragraph

text: in existing cities) occur at ground level, while all social life, now free to
label: Paragraph

text: develop without any impediment, takes place within a vast structure
label: Paragraph

text: raised on pi/otis. This structure, which forms a network that will even-
label: Paragraph

text: tually cover the entire globe, is a continuous multi-storey loft space
label: Paragraph

text: containing all living and social functions, which will be continuously
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt by the population, aided by cybernetic machines. The perma-
label: Paragraph

text: nent structure, like that of Le Corbusier’s Algiers viaduct, is a series of
label: Paragraph

text: fixed floorplates constituting the ‘ground levels’ of the city (unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Cedric Price’s Fun Palace where the floors are mobile). The population
label: Paragraph

text: will migrate at will from one part of the city to another and communi-
label: Paragraph

text: ties will continually form and reform. Since work has been abolished,
label: Paragraph

text: life will be spent in creative social interaction and imaginative play in
label: Paragraph

text: an environment that has been completely aestheticized. Contrary to
label: Paragraph

text: Constant’s avowed intentions, the dominant impression of this aes-
label: Paragraph

text: thetic Utopia is one of boredom and claustrophobia. It is like an
label: Paragraph

text: endless shopping mall without exit signs. Moreover, while social life is
label: Paragraph

text: ina state of constant agitation, economics and government seem, like
label: Paragraph

text: industrial production, to have vanished into a state of automated
label: Paragraph

text: perfection. It pictures a lobotomized world from which power and
label: Paragraph

text: conflict have been eradicated.
label: Paragraph

text: Whether Megastructures emphasize a relatively fixed infrastruc-
label: Paragraph

text: ture or its self-regulating, responsive infill, they are all predicated on a
label: Paragraph

text: dominant idea—that of the city as an open web or network, the con-
label: Paragraph

text: tents of which can develop according to an internal dynamic. In
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to the traditional Cartesian schema promoted by the Athens
label: Paragraph

text: Charter, according to which the city consists of a closed hierarchy of
label: Paragraph

text: discrete parts controlled by a centre, the Megastructural city is pre-
label: Paragraph

text: sented as an indivisible, organic, self-regulating whole. Problems seem
label: Paragraph

text: to arise when this abstract concept is hypostasized and given form as an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural image. The idea immediately takes on the clothing of a
label: Paragraph

text: Utopia or a dystopia, depending on whether the hidden mechanism of
label: Paragraph

text: the system is read as benign or sinister. It is all too easy to see
label: Paragraph

text: Constant’s New Babylon, for example, as an allegory for a post-indus-
label: Paragraph

text: trial, capitalist world, in which an invisible network, though able to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain and reproduce itself efficiently, is no longer guided by any
label: Paragraph

text: rational telos.

text: The defining moment for the introduction of the Modern Movement
label: Title

text: into America is usually seen to have been the exhibition at the New
label: Paragraph

text: York Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) of 1932 and the accompanying
label: Paragraph

text: book, The International Style, by Philip Johnson and Henry Russell
label: Caption

text: Hitchcock. This book presented the Modern Movement as an inci-
label: Paragraph

text: dent in the evolution of style, and downplayed its progressive social
label: Paragraph

text: content. The explanation for this can probably be found in the differ-
label: Paragraph

text: ent cultural and political conditions prevailing in America and Europe
label: Title

text: at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, the period between 1910 and 1930 was one of unprece-
label: Paragraph

text: dented social and cultural upheaval. Sweeping social reforms were
label: Paragraph

text: being initiated by liberal governments, particularly in the realm of
label: Paragraph

text: public housing. At the same time there was a powerful avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: movement in all the arts supported by a small but influential minority
label: Paragraph

text: of the cultural elite. During the same period in America this paral-
label: Paragraph

text: lelism between socially progressive ideas and the artistic avant-garde
label: Title

text: was largely lacking. Garden City settlements of the 1920s and 1930s,
label: Paragraph

text: like Sunnyside Gardens in New York, Radburn in New Jersey, and
label: Paragraph

text: Greenbelt near Washington, DC, all by Clarence Stein and Henry
label: Caption

text: Wright, were still basically within the Arts and Crafts tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Projects derived from the 1920s European avant-garde, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Stonorov and Kastner's Carl Mackley Houses in Philadelphia, were
label: Paragraph

text: rare. Given the lack of commonly perceived connection between the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde and social reform it is hardly surprising that Hitchcock
label: Paragraph

text: and Johnson should have emphasized the purely stylistic aspects of the
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Movement. Yet there were other voices; for example, in paral-
label: Paragraph

text: lel with the ‘International Style’ exhibit, MoMA mounted an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of social housing curated by the architectural critic Lewis
label: Caption

text: Mumford (1895-1990) and his assistant Catherine Bauer, which
label: Paragraph

text: included examples of the Arts and Crafts movement and Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Sachlichkeit in Germany.
