text: Lewis Mumford’s writings in the 1920s still carried the imprint of
label: Paragraph

text: William Morris’s rejection of modern technology. But towards the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the decade he came increasingly under the influence of the optimistic
label: Paragraph

text: evolutionism of the Scottish urbanist Patrick Geddes. According to
label: Paragraph

text: Geddes, the present ‘paleotechnic’ phase in civilization would give way
label: Paragraph

text: to a ‘neotechnic’ phase in which electricity would succeed coal as a
label: Paragraph

text: source of power, and biological principles would replace mechanistic
label: Paragraph

text: ones. After visiting the new housing in Weimar Germany in 1932,
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford became convinced that such a neotechnic phase was in the
label: Paragraph

text: making. His books Technics and Civilization (1934) and The Culture of
label: Paragraph

text: Cities (1938) contained the essence of his new philosophy.
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford’s partner on the German tour was Catherine Bauer—a
label: Paragraph

text: young writer whose visit to Ernst May’s New Frankfurt two years
label: Title

text: earlier had, in her own words, transformed her ‘from an aesthete into a
label: Paragraph

text: housing reformer’. After turning the research material collected on the
label: Paragraph

text: German tour into a book, Modern Housing, she became acknowledged
label: Paragraph

text: as the foremost American expert on social housing. Bauer realized
label: Paragraph

text: (unlike Mumford) that the success of social housing in America
label: Paragraph

text: depended on grass-roots political action. In 1934, she became director
label: Paragraph

text: of the Philadelphia Labor Housing Conference, founded by the archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tect Oskar Stonorov and John Edelman of the Hosiery Workers
label: Title

text: Union, whose purpose—ultimately abortive—was to create a labour-
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored housing cooperative.
label: Paragraph

text: Mumford and Bauer’s enthusiasm for the German housing move-
label: Paragraph

text: ment must be seen against the background of the general openness to
label: Paragraph

text: European social ideas that characterized the New Deal, as the
label: Paragraph

text: Roosevelt administration searched for ways to alleviate the effects of
label: Paragraph

text: the Depression. But the flow of ideas across the Atlantic in the inter-
label: Paragraph

text: war period was not only from east to west. Especially during the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s, European reformers, both in Western Europe and in Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Russia, envious of the high living standards of American workers,
label: Paragraph

text: sought to harness American ideas to their various programmes of
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction and reform. American technology and production
label: Title

text: management were emulated by European industry and became impor-
label: Paragraph

text: tant early points of reference for the Modern Movement.?
label: Paragraph

text: After the Second World War the situation changed radically.
label: Paragraph

text: America emerged from the war as the dominant power and as the cred-
label: Paragraph

text: itor of an impoverished and ruined Europe. Though some of the
label: Paragraph

text: welfare programmes inaugurated by the New Deal remained intact,
label: Paragraph

text: there was now unbounded confidence in American capitalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Modern architecture became accepted worldwide by the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: profession, but it was pursued under totally different political condi-
label: Paragraph

text: tions in America and Europe. In the welfare state economies of
label: Paragraph

text: post-war Europe modern architecture, whether orthodox or revision-
label: Paragraph

text: ist, became the norm for public projects. Within this ethos architects,
label: Paragraph

text: working either in government or private offices, began to study prob-
label: Paragraph

text: lems of large-scale architectural production. In England in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s, for example, Hertfordshire County Council implemented a
label: Paragraph

text: school programme based on a modular system of prefabrication.* In
label: Paragraph

text: Europe as a whole the many points of connection between modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and the welfare state encouraged the experimental work of
label: Paragraph

text: Team X and the Megastructuralist movements (see pages 217 and 223).
label: Paragraph

text: During the same period in America the most vital developments in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture were in the private sector. Even public projects
label: Paragraph

text: were financed by private agencies (albeit with federal or state help) and
label: Paragraph

text: this tended to inhibit, though it did not altogether eliminate, the
label: Paragraph

text: development of an ideology-driven Modernism. Precisely because of
label: Paragraph

text: the different conditions of architectural production in America and
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, however, the mutual influence was still strong. In Europe this
label: Paragraph

text: influence was chiefly felt in two areas: the first, technology, reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: the tradition of Modernist rationalism; the second, popular and
label: Paragraph

text: rapidly changing cultural forms, ran counter to it.
label: Paragraph

text: In this chapter three major themes will be examined: firstly, the
label: Paragraph

text: individual house—in particular, the Case Study House Program; sec-
label: Paragraph

text: ondly, corporate office building; and thirdly, critiques of Modernist
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism, the pressures of consumerism, and the search for an archi-
label: Paragraph

text: tecture of public symbolism.
label: Paragraph

text: The Case Study House Program
label: Title

text: In the 1920s in Western Europe, the individual house had played an
label: Paragraph

text: important role in the birth of the Modern Movement. But in the two
label: Paragraph

text: decades after the Second World War, European domestic building was
label: Paragraph

text: largely confined to government housing programmes, which consisted
label: Paragraph

text: mostly of high-rise apartments or row houses in the cities or the new
label: Paragraph

text: towns. In America, by contrast, most new housing took the form of
label: Paragraph

text: large suburban settlements, made necessary by the accelerated migra-
label: Paragraph

text: tion of white middle-class families from the cities to the outer suburbs
label: Paragraph

text: and carried out by private developers.* At the same time there was a
label: Paragraph

text: large market in one-off family houses, extending from the modest and
label: Paragraph

text: pre-designed to the lavish and purpose-designed.
label: Paragraph

text: The stylistic tendencies within the housing market were the result
label: Paragraph

text: of a complex interplay between various interested parties, including
label: Paragraph

text: the loan agencies, the building industry, and professional and cultural
label: Title

text: pressure groups. Museums such as the Museum of Modern Art in
label: Paragraph

text: New York and progressive journals such as Architectural Record tried to
label: Paragraph

text: popularize modern house design, but with only modest success. In 1951
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Record, commenting on a House of Ideas sponsored by the
label: Paragraph

text: journal House and Garden, described it as a fusion of the ‘crisp, clean
label: Paragraph

text: lines of the International Style and the rambling openness of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ranch House Style’. The design typified a ‘no-nonsense’ Modernism
label: Paragraph

text: unencumbered by theory which gained some popularity in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States in the rgsos.°
label: Paragraph

text: In this encounter between Modernism and the housing market, the
label: Paragraph

text: example of southern California played a crucial role. Ever since the
label: Paragraph

text: early years of the twentieth century, with such buildings as the Gamble
label: Paragraph

text: House by Greene and Greene (1907-8} and Dodge House by Irving
label: Caption

text: Gill (1914-16), Los Angeles had shown itself to be receptive to an inno-
label: Paragraph

text: vative domestic architecture. This tradition had been continued in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1920s with the Los Angeles houses of Frank Lloyd Wright and the
label: Paragraph

text: work of Austrian immigrants Rudolph Schindler (1887-1953) and
label: Paragraph

text: Richard Neutra (1892-1970)—for example, the justly admired houses
label: Paragraph

text: that each of them built for Dr Phillip Lovell (1923-5 and 1927-9
label: Paragraph

text: respectively).
label: Paragraph

text: Tt was in Los Angeles after the Second World War that a vigorous
label: Paragraph

text: attempt was made to influence the more expensive end of the post-war
label: Paragraph

text: house market in the direction of modern architecture: the Case Study
label: Title

text: House Program. This was initiated by John Entenza, an amateur of
label: Paragraph

text: modern art and architecture who became owner-editor of the maga-
label: Paragraph

text: zine Arts and Architecture in 1938, turning it into a mouthpiece of the
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde. In the July issue of 1944 Entenza—together with photog-
label: Paragraph

text: rapher and graphic artist Herbert Matter and architects and designers
label: Title

text: Ray and Charles Eames (1912-88 and 1907-78), Eero Saarinen
label: Title

text: (tgr0—61), and Richard Buckminster Fuller (1895-1983)—published a
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto calling for the application of wartime technology to the
label: Paragraph

text: post-war housing problem. The montages by Herbert Matter
label: Caption

text: announcing the manifesto showed a familiarity with Futurist and
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivist graphics, but they placed a new emphasis on the
label: Paragraph

text: analogy between machines, the human nervous system, and molecular
label: Paragraph

text: structures. The manifesto recast Bauhaus and Corbusian ideology in
label: Paragraph

text: terms of post-war American technology. In defining the principles on
label: Paragraph

text: which the post-war house should be based, it declared:
label: Paragraph

text: The house is an instrument of service. Degrees of service are real and can be
label: Paragraph

text: measured. They are not dependent on taste. The house should not assert itself
label: Paragraph

text: by its architectural design. In fact, the better integrated the services of the
label: Paragraph

text: house become, the less one is apt to be conscious of the physical way in which
label: Paragraph

text: it has been done. The kitchen, bathroom, bedroom, utilities, and storage will
label: Paragraph

text: profit most by an industrialized system of prefabrication. In the living—recre-
label: Paragraph

text: ational areas variation becomes a valid personal preference. A designer must
label: Paragraph

text: know what the house must supply to meet the physiological and psychological
label: Paragraph

text: needs of the members of the family.*
label: Paragraph

text: Optimistic and positivistic in tone, the manifesto promoted the belief
label: Paragraph

text: that an art based on psychological laws and an architecture based on
label: Paragraph

text: scientific method would lead to a unified culture in tune with the
label: Paragraph

text: modern age. The aim of the manifesto was not social revolution but a
label: Paragraph

text: revolution in aesthetics, starting with the enlightened bourgeoisie and
label: Paragraph

text: filtering down to the masses. Nonetheless, the manifesto had a moral
label: Paragraph

text: and social as well as an aesthetic agenda: the particular aesthetic it pro-
label: Paragraph

text: moted was one of transparency and ‘authenticity’, inseparable, it was
label: Paragraph

text: thought, from the ideals of a rational and just social order.
label: Paragraph

text: Prefabrication techniques, combining standardization and choice,
label: Paragraph

text: would make the new aesthetic principles available to everyone. Where
label: Paragraph

text: it differed from the European Modern Movement and from social
label: Paragraph

text: reformers like Lewis Mumford and Catherine Bauer was in its
label: Paragraph

text: assumption that the uniform culture it envisaged was compatible with
label: Paragraph

text: a market-based capitalism.
label: Paragraph

text: To carry out this ambitious agenda Entenza commissioned or
label: Paragraph

text: adopted a series of suburban houses in southern California by
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist architects, including among others William Wurster
label: Paragraph

text: (1895-1973), Ralph Rapson (b. 1914), and Richard Neutra, in order to
label: Paragraph

text: build up a ‘case study’ of the new domestic architecture. In spite of their
label: Paragraph

text: differences these houses had many features in common, not all of
label: Paragraph

text: which were derived from the theory presented in the manifesto. They
label: Paragraph

text: were, for a start, nearly all of one storey with flat roofs. The plans were
label: Paragraph

text: open and informal but tended to be bi-nuclear, the living rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: bedrooms being remote from each other. The inside was opened up to
label: Paragraph

text: the outside by means of large areas of glazing. A tendency towards pic-
label: Paragraph

text: turesque dispersal was counteracted by the economic need for cubic
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity. Nearly all the houses had unrendered brick fireplaces—a
label: Paragraph

text: reassuring reference to the pre-industrial past. The layouts reflected a
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat ritualized suburban life style—non-rational and conformist
label: Paragraph

text: rather than rational and free as the theory claimed. Despite the use of
label: Paragraph

text: forms connoting prefabrication and mechanization most of the houses
label: Paragraph

text: were built of blockwork with wood framing, and the flexibility of the
label: Paragraph

text: plans owed as much to traditional American building techniques as
label: Paragraph

text: they did to new technology and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 1950, the Case Study houses underwent a marked change,
label: Paragraph

text: which first becomes noticeable in those by Raphael Soriano (1907-88),
label: Paragraph

text: Craig Ellwood (1922-92), and Pierre Koenig (b. 1925) [161]. In these
label: Paragraph

text: houses there was a new concentration on modular construction and
label: Paragraph

text: prefabrication. The houses were thought of more as assembled systems
label: Paragraph

text: than as ‘designs’ in the traditional sense. It became possible to talk ofan
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of steel and glass. Nearly all the houses now had steel
label: Paragraph

text: frames and the structure and method of assembly became clearly
label: Paragraph

text: visible while the plans became simpler and less picturesque. Discussing
label: Paragraph

text: Craig Ellwood’s House 17 of 195475, the Italian journal Domus wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: ‘In fact, we do not find here innovations in the scheme of composition,
label: Paragraph

text: in the treatment of space, structure or materials, but solutions of
label: Paragraph

text: details, perfections of equipment and materials, which make this
label: Paragraph

text: architecture more profound and more concrete.”
label: Paragraph

text: Two Case Study houses built between 1945 and 1949 stand some-
label: Paragraph

text: what apart from the other houses of the earlier phase, though they
label: Paragraph

text: foreshadow the second phase in many ways: Case Study House g, built

label: Paragraph

text: The corporate office building
label: Title

text: Perhaps the greatest single achievement of American architecture after
label: Paragraph

text: the Second World War was the establishment of the modern corporate
label: Paragraph

text: office building as a type, imitated all over the world. Skidmore,
label: Paragraph

text: Owings, and Merrill (SOM) were the leaders of this development.
label: Paragraph

text: Founded in Chicago in 1933 by Nathaniel Owings (1903-84) and Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore (1897-1962), the firm came to prominence during the war
label: Paragraph

text: with the commission to build the city of Oak Ridge in Tennessee for
label: Paragraph

text: the Manhattan Project for the development of the atomic bomb. After
label: Paragraph

text: the war, the firm grew into a huge multi-partner organization with
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: a Miesian rather than a Corbusian prototype. From 1952, indeed, Mies

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: space.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ‘military—industrial complex’.

text: Mies van der Rohe in America
label: Title

text: The American work of Mies van der Rohe occupies a position that is
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The critique of corporatism
label: Title

text: Mies’s carefully worked out idealist philosophy and his disdain for the
label: Paragraph

text: trivia of everyday life in favour of a purified expression of the Zeitgeist
label: Paragraph

text: coincided exactly with the worldly demands of corporate discipline—a
label: Paragraph

text: discipline that was accepted by SOM uncritically and on its own terms.
label: Paragraph

text: It was precisely this corporate discipline that was attacked by writers
label: Paragraph

text: like David Riesman (The Lonely Crowd, 1950) and William H. Whyte
label: Paragraph

text: (The Organisation Man, 1956), who saw the corporation as a dehuman-
label: Paragraph

text: ized collective producing a new type of ‘other-directed’ character,
label: Paragraph

text: nervously conforming to the opinions of (corporate) peers. These crit-
label: Paragraph

text: icisms were markedly different from those of late-nineteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: German sociologists like Georg Simmel. Whereas for Simmel indi-
label: Paragraph

text: vidualism (the blasé type) was a defensive mechanism developed to
label: Paragraph

text: deal with the loss of community in an economy based on money, for
label: Paragraph

text: Reisman and Whyte individualism was a primary American virtue,
label: Paragraph

text: threatened by corporate conformism.
label: Paragraph

text: The critique of corporatism was also mounted on a more political
label: Paragraph

text: level. C. Wright Mills (The Power Elite, 1956) saw the signs of a new,
label: Paragraph

text: insidious kind of totalitarianism in the very dispersal of power that was
label: Paragraph

text: the essence of corporate capitalism—evident in the multiple links
label: Paragraph

text: between the corporations, the military, and government. Mills’s pes-
label: Paragraph

text: simism was not shared, however, by fellow sociologist Talcott Parsons,
label: Paragraph

text: for whom the web-like structure of modern political power was symp-
label: Paragraph

text: tomatic of a well-performing, self-regulating social system that
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily resulted in the sacrifice of the individual to the organic
label: Paragraph

text: whole (see Systems theory, page 220).

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Corporation, breaking with the Fordist tradition, adapted their pro-

text: Adolf Behne’s distinction between ‘functionalism’ and ‘rationalism’,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s concept of the free plan, and the dislocation in Mies van
label: Paragraph

text: der Rohe’s American phase between the regular building envelope and
label: Paragraph

text: its variable content, were merely particular, working formulations of a
label: Paragraph

text: more general problem of disjunction.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn, whether we see his work as derived from Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc or the classical tradition, started from the same problem, but
label: Paragraph

text: moved in a different direction. This direction was being explored at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time by Team X, and had been adumbrated by Le Corbusier in
label: Paragraph

text: his accentuation of each living cell in the Unité d’Habitation and other
label: Paragraph

text: post-war projects. For Kahn—going much further than Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: in this direction—architecture only took on meaning when a unit of
label: Paragraph

text: structure coincided with a unit of habitable space. This made the free
label: Paragraph

text: plan inoperative and gave rise to a new problem: instead of being free to
label: Paragraph

text: develop independently, as they were according to the logic of the free
label: Paragraph

text: plan, ideal and circumstantial orders were now locked in a dialectic,
label: Paragraph

text: directing attention to the conflict between transcendent architectural
label: Paragraph

text: values and the contingencies of the modern economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn belonged firmly to the Modernist tradition in at least
label: Paragraph

text: one respect: he wanted to create an architecture that would embody a
label: Paragraph

text: new politico-moral order. In his attempt to achieve this he arrived at a
label: Paragraph

text: surprising new formulation of an old problem—how to achieve an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that would be absolutely new but at the same time would
label: Paragraph

text: reaffirm timeless architectural truths.
label: Paragraph

text: The effect of this effort was to bring to a head and accelerate the
label: Paragraph

text: existing crisis within the Modern Movement. Rational functionalism
label: Paragraph

text: had seemed to take on a new lease of life in post-war America, but by
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s its principles seemed incapable of dealing with the web-like
label: Paragraph

text: complexities of late capitalism. The Utopian promise ofa new, unified,
label: Paragraph

text: and universal architecture was becoming increasingly implausible. If
label: Paragraph

text: there could still be said to be a ‘spirit of the epoch’, a Zeitgeist, it was
label: Paragraph

text: now the self-contradictory one of pluralism. Modernism was to
label: Paragraph

text: survive, but only after abandoning its totalizing claims and by a process
label: Paragraph

text: of continual self-cancellation. Paradoxically, the work of Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn—anchored as it was in a belief in a transcendent order—was one
label: Paragraph

text: of the chief propelling agents in this emerging regime of uncertainty.
